LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”  

There was something almost boyish in his tone, a vulnerability that caught me off guard. The afternoon light filtered through the drawn blinds of his library, casting long, slanting shadows across the rows of untouched books. Gatsby’s face was earnest, his eyes searching mine for some sign of forgiveness.  

I hesitated before answering. The truth was, I hadn’t been angry—only unsettled. The way he had spoken about Daisy, with such raw desperation, had left me uneasy. It was as if he were clinging to a dream that had long since slipped through his fingers, yet he refused to acknowledge it.  

“It’s nothing,” I said at last, though the words felt hollow.  

Gatsby’s expression flickered, as if he sensed my reluctance. He leaned back slightly, his fingers drumming against the arm of his chair. “You see, old sport, I’ve waited so long for this. I can’t afford any missteps now.”  

There it was again—that quiet intensity, the unshakable belief that he could rewrite the past. I studied him for a moment, this man who had built an empire out of sheer will, who threw parties the likes of which the world had never seen, all for the sake of a woman who had moved on without him.  

“Gatsby,” I began carefully, “do you ever think that perhaps—”  

But he cut me off with a wave of his hand, his smile tight. “No, no. I know what you’re going to say. That it’s been years, that people change. But not Daisy. Not really.”  

His certainty was almost painful to witness. I wanted to tell him that the Daisy he remembered—the golden girl of his youth—was gone, replaced by a woman hardened by time and circumstance. But how could I? He had built his entire life around the idea of her, and to shatter that illusion would be to destroy him.  

Instead, I said nothing, and the silence stretched between us like the Long Island Sound on a windless day.  

After a moment, Gatsby stood abruptly, smoothing his jacket with restless hands. “Well, no matter. You’ll come to dinner tomorrow, won’t you? Daisy will be there.”  

There was no refusing him. I nodded, and his face lit up with relief. “Splendid! It’s all going to be splendid, old sport. You’ll see.”  

As I left his mansion that evening, I couldn’t shake the feeling that I was watching a man walk blindly toward the edge of a cliff. Gatsby’s faith in his dream was unshakable, but dreams, I knew, were fragile things. And the world had a way of crushing them beneath its weight.  

The green light across the bay flickered in the distance, a silent beacon of hope—or perhaps, a warning.

events.title: Jordan Recounts Daisy and Gatsby's Early Romance and Her Pre-Wedding Crisis
detailed_summary: The narrative shifts to Jordan Baker telling Nick a story later that afternoon in the Plaza Hotel's tea-garden.
Jordan recalls walking in Louisville in October 1917, wearing distinctive English shoes.
She describes passing Daisy Fay's house; Daisy, then eighteen and Louisville's most popular girl, constantly received calls from officers stationed at Camp Taylor.
Jordan recounts seeing Daisy sitting in her white roadster beside the curb with a lieutenant Jordan hadn't seen before.
The couple was so intensely focused on each other they didn't notice Jordan until she was very close.
Daisy called Jordan over, flattering her by wanting to speak to her.
Daisy asked Jordan to relay a message that she couldn't make it to the Red Cross that day.
Jordan distinctly remembers the way the lieutenant looked at Daisy while she spoke – a look of adoration she found romantic and memorable.
Jordan reveals the lieutenant's name was Jay Gatsby, and she didn't recognize him again for over four years, not even initially after meeting him on Long Island.
Jordan explains that by the following year (1918), she was occupied with her own social life and golf tournaments and saw less of Daisy.
Rumors circulated about Daisy's mother finding her packing to go to New York to bid farewell to a soldier heading overseas; she was stopped and estranged from her family for weeks.
After that incident, Daisy stopped socializing with soldiers and only associated with local young men unfit for military service.
By the autumn of 1919, Daisy was cheerful again, had her debutante presentation after the armistice, and was reportedly engaged by February.
In June, she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago in an exceptionally grand wedding for Louisville.
Tom arrived with a large entourage, rented an entire hotel floor, and gave Daisy a pearl necklace valued at $350,000 the day before the ceremony.
Jordan, serving as a bridesmaid, entered Daisy's room thirty minutes before the bridal dinner.
She found Daisy lying on her bed, beautifully dressed but extremely drunk, holding a bottle of Sauterne and a letter.
Daisy, admitting she'd never drunk before, urged Jordan to congratulate her.
Scared, Jordan asked what was wrong.
Daisy retrieved the pearl necklace from a wastebasket, telling Jordan to return it to its owner and declare that 'Daisy's change' her mind.'
Daisy then broke down, crying hysterically.
Jordan fetched Daisy's mother's maid; they locked the door and forced Daisy into a cold bath.
Daisy clung to the letter, taking it into the tub until it dissolved into a wet pulp, finally allowing Jordan to place the remains in the soap dish.
Daisy spoke no further about the incident.
They revived her with smelling salts, applied ice, dressed her, and half an hour later, she emerged composed with the pearls around her neck.
The following day at 5 PM, she married Tom Buchanan calmly and left for a three-month honeymoon in the South Seas.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Next day at five o’clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months’ trip to the South Seas.

events.text_segment:
One October day in nineteen-seventeen—
(said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting up very straight on a straight chair in the tea-garden at the Plaza Hotel)
—I was walking along from one place to another, half on the sidewalks and half on the lawns. I was happier on the lawns because I had on shoes from England with rubber knobs on the soles that bit into the soft ground. I had on a new plaid skirt also that blew a little in the wind, and whenever this happened the red, white, and blue banners in front of all the houses stretched out stiff and said tut-tut-tut-tut, in a disapproving way.
The largest of the banners and the largest of the lawns belonged to Daisy Fay’s house. She was just eighteen, two years older than me, and by far the most popular of all the young girls in Louisville. She dressed in white, and had a little white roadster, and all day long the telephone rang in her house and excited young officers from Camp Taylor demanded the privilege of monopolizing her that night. “Anyways, for an hour!”
When I came opposite her house that morning her white roadster was beside the kerb, and she was sitting in it with a lieutenant I had never seen before. They were so engrossed in each other that she didn’t see me until I was five feet away.
“Hello, Jordan,” she called unexpectedly. “Please come here.”
I was flattered that she wanted to speak to me, because of all the older girls I admired her most. She asked me if I was going to the Red Cross to make bandages. I was. Well, then, would I tell them that she couldn’t come that day? The officer looked at Daisy while she was speaking, in a way that every young girl wants to be looked at sometime, and because it seemed romantic to me I have remembered the incident ever since. His name was Jay Gatsby, and I didn’t lay eyes on him again for over four years—even after I’d met him on Long Island I didn’t realize it was the same man.
That was nineteen-seventeen. By the next year I had a few beaux myself, and I began to play in tournaments, so I didn’t see Daisy very often. She went with a slightly older crowd—when she went with anyone at all. Wild rumours were circulating about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag one winter night to go to New York and say goodbye to a soldier who was going overseas. She was effectually prevented, but she wasn’t on speaking terms with her family for several weeks. After that she didn’t play around with the soldiers any more, but only with a few flat-footed, shortsighted young men in town, who couldn’t get into the army at all.
By the next autumn she was gay again, gay as ever. She had a début after the armistice, and in February she was presumably engaged to a man from New Orleans. In June she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago, with more pomp and circumstance than Louisville ever knew before. He came down with a hundred people in four private cars, and hired a whole floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave her a string of pearls valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
I was a bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the June night in her flowered dress—and as drunk as a monkey. She had a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.
“ ’Gratulate me,” she muttered. “Never had a drink before, but oh how I do enjoy it.”
“What’s the matter, Daisy?”
I was scared, I can tell you; I’d never seen a girl like that before.
“Here, dearies.” She groped around in a wastebasket she had with her on the bed and pulled out the string of pearls. “Take ’em downstairs and give ’em back to whoever they belong to. Tell ’em all Daisy’s change’ her mine. Say: ‘Daisy’s change’ her mine!’ ”
She began to cry—she cried and cried. I rushed out and found her mother’s maid, and we locked the door and got her into a cold bath. She wouldn’t let go of the letter. She took it into the tub with her and squeezed it up in a wet ball, and only let me leave it in the soap-dish when she saw that it was coming to pieces like snow.
But she didn’t say another word. We gave her spirits of ammonia and put ice on her forehead and hooked her back into her dress, and half an hour later, when we walked out of the room, the pearls were around her neck and the incident was over. Next day at five o’clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months’ trip to the South Seas.

*"I was a bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the June night in her flowered dress—and as drunk as a monkey. She had a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.*  

*"‘’Gratulate me,’ she muttered. ‘Never had a drink before, but oh how I do enjoy it.’*  

*"‘What’s the matter, Daisy?’*  

*"I was scared, I can tell you; I’d never seen a girl like that before.*  

*"‘Here, deares’.’ She groped around in a waste-basket she had with her on the bed and pulled out the string of pearls. ‘Take ’em down-stairs and give ’em back to whoever they belong to. Tell ’em all Daisy’s change’ her mine. Say: ‘Daisy’s change’ her mine!’’*  

*"She began to cry—she cried and cried. I rushed out and found her mother’s maid, and we locked the door and got her into a cold bath. She wouldn’t let go of the letter. She took it into the tub with her and squeezed it up into a wet ball, and only let me leave it in the soap-dish when she saw that it was coming to pieces like snow.*  

*"But she didn’t say another word. We gave her spirits of ammonia and put ice on her forehead and hooked her back into her dress, and half an hour later, when we walked out of the room, the pearls were around her neck and the incident was over. Next day at five o’clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months’ trip to the South Seas."*  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
One October day in nineteen-seventeen—the air crisp with the promise of autumn and the leaves on West Egg’s trees turning gold—I found myself standing on the lawn of Jay Gatsby’s mansion, though I scarcely knew the man then. He was little more than a name whispered in awe at parties, a figure shrouded in mystery and rumor. Yet there I was, an accidental guest at one of his legendary gatherings, drawn in by the music and the laughter that spilled from his house like champagne from an overfilled glass.  

The party was in full swing, the kind of affair where strangers became fast friends and the night stretched on with no end in sight. Women in shimmering dresses twirled under the chandeliers, their laughter mingling with the jazz that pulsed through the rooms. Men in sharp suits leaned against the grand piano, glasses in hand, discussing stocks and bootlegging with equal fervor. And above it all, presiding like some benevolent but distant host, was Gatsby himself—watching, always watching, as if searching for something just beyond his reach.  

I had just accepted a drink from a passing waiter when I noticed him standing alone on the terrace, his gaze fixed on the green light blinking across the bay. There was something unbearably lonely in the way he stood there, separate from the revelry he had created. It struck me then that all of this—the mansion, the parties, the wealth—was merely a stage, and Gatsby was an actor playing a role he had written for himself long ago.  

“Quite a sight, isn’t it?” a voice beside me said. I turned to see a man with sharp, knowing eyes—later, I would learn he was Meyer Wolfsheim, Gatsby’s shadowy associate. He followed my gaze toward the terrace and chuckled. “Always looking across the water, that one. You’d think he’d be satisfied with all this.” He gestured vaguely at the opulence around us.  

“What’s over there?” I asked, though I already knew.  

Wolfsheim’s smile was cryptic. “The past, my boy. The past.”  

Before I could ask more, Gatsby turned and caught sight of us. His expression shifted instantly, the melancholy vanishing beneath that practiced, dazzling smile. He strode forward, hand extended. “I don’t believe we’ve met,” he said, his voice warm, inviting. “Jay Gatsby.”  

That was the first time I truly saw him—not as the myth, but as the man. And though I couldn’t have known it then, that moment marked the beginning of a story that would unravel like a thread pulled from a finely woven tapestry, revealing the truth beneath the glittering façade.  

For Gatsby, that green light was more than just a beacon across the bay. It was a dream, a promise, a ghost of what might have been. And like all dreams, it was just out of reach—no matter how far he stretched his hand.  

The rest, as they say, is history. But history, in Gatsby’s case, was never just the past. It was the thing he carried with him, always, like the weight of his own name. And on that October night, with the leaves falling and the music playing, none of us could have guessed how heavy that weight truly was.

events.title: Jordan Details Daisy's Marriage, Tom's Infidelity, and Gatsby's Reappearance
detailed_summary: Jordan continues her story, recalling seeing the Buchanans in Santa Barbara after their honeymoon.
She describes Daisy appearing utterly infatuated with Tom, becoming anxious if he briefly left the room and gazing at him with 'unfathomable delight'.
Jordan found their intense affection touching, though slightly amusing.
However, a week after Jordan's visit, Tom was involved in a car accident on the Ventura road.
The incident became public because his passenger, a chambermaid from the Santa Barbara Hotel, broke her arm, exposing Tom's early infidelity.
The following April, Daisy gave birth to their daughter.
The Buchanans subsequently spent a year traveling in France (Cannes, Deauville).
Jordan saw them during their time abroad.
They eventually returned to the US and settled in Chicago.
Daisy became a popular figure in Chicago's young, wealthy, and 'wild' social set.
Jordan emphasizes that Daisy maintained an 'absolutely perfect reputation'.
She attributes this partly to Daisy's abstinence from alcohol, which allowed her to maintain composure and discretion among hard-drinking peers.
Jordan muses on whether Daisy ever had affairs, alluding to an enigmatic quality in Daisy's voice.
Jordan brings the story closer to the present, explaining that about six weeks ago, Daisy heard Gatsby's name for the first time in years.
This occurred when Jordan asked Nick if he knew Gatsby (referencing their earlier conversation).
After Nick left that day, Daisy came to Jordan's room, woke her, and asked, 'What Gatsby?'.
When Jordan (half-asleep) described him, Daisy reacted strangely, saying it must be the man she used to know.

Jordan states that it was only at that moment that she finally connected the wealthy Jay Gatsby of West Egg with the young lieutenant Daisy had been with in the white roadster years earlier in Louisville.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It wasn’t until then that I connected this Gatsby with the officer in her white car.

events.text_segment:
I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband. If he left the room for a minute she’d look around uneasily, and say: “Where’s Tom gone?” and wear the most abstracted expression until she saw him coming in the door. She used to sit on the sand with his head in her lap by the hour, rubbing her fingers over his eyes and looking at him with unfathomable delight. It was touching to see them together—it made you laugh in a hushed, fascinated way. That was in August. A week after I left Santa Barbara Tom ran into a wagon on the Ventura road one night, and ripped a front wheel off his car. The girl who was with him got into the papers, too, because her arm was broken—she was one of the chambermaids in the Santa Barbara Hotel.
The next April Daisy had her little girl, and they went to France for a year. I saw them one spring in Cannes, and later in Deauville, and then they came back to Chicago to settle down. Daisy was popular in Chicago, as you know. They moved with a fast crowd, all of them young and rich and wild, but she came out with an absolutely perfect reputation. Perhaps because she doesn’t drink. It’s a great advantage not to drink among hard-drinking people. You can hold your tongue and, moreover, you can time any little irregularity of your own so that everybody else is so blind that they don’t see or care. Perhaps Daisy never went in for amour at all—and yet there’s something in that voice of hers…
Well, about six weeks ago, she heard the name Gatsby for the first time in years. It was when I asked you—do you remember?—if you knew Gatsby in West Egg. After you had gone home she came into my room and woke me up, and said: “What Gatsby?” and when I described him—I was half asleep—she said in the strangest voice that it must be the man she used to know. It wasn’t until then that I connected this Gatsby with the officer in her white car.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband. Daisy was radiant, her laughter ringing through the air like the chime of silver bells, her eyes alight with a fervor I hadn’t seen since before the war. Tom, for his part, seemed to swell with pride, his broad shoulders squared as if to shield her from the world. They moved through the rooms of their rented villa like figures in a painting, perfectly composed, untouchable.  

But even then, I sensed something beneath the surface—a tension, a quiet desperation. Daisy’s laughter was too bright, her gestures too deliberate. Once, when she thought no one was looking, I caught her staring out at the ocean, her face blank, as if the weight of her own happiness had suddenly become too much to bear. Tom, ever oblivious, clapped a hand on my shoulder and boasted about their plans—another trip, another party, another distraction.  

I wondered if he knew. If he saw the way her fingers trembled when she lit a cigarette, or how her voice faltered just slightly when she spoke his name. Love, I thought, was a strange and fragile thing—capable of both blinding devotion and quiet ruin. Daisy had chosen her path, wrapped herself in the security of Tom’s world, but at what cost?  

Later that evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky in hues of gold and crimson, I overheard her murmur something to him—a private joke, perhaps, or a plea. Tom laughed, loud and careless, and pulled her close. She went willingly, her smile never slipping, but her eyes—those brilliant, tragic eyes—told another story.  

I left Santa Barbara the next morning, carrying with me the image of a woman who loved too much and too little, all at once. And I couldn’t help but think that some fires burn so fiercely only because they know, deep down, they cannot last.

events.title: Jordan Explains Gatsby's True Motive and His Request
detailed_summary: Jordan concludes her narrative as she and Nick ride through Central Park in a carriage at twilight.
Nick observes that the connection seems like a 'strange coincidence'.
Jordan refutes this, stating it was entirely intentional.
She reveals the crucial information: Gatsby purchased his West Egg mansion solely because it was situated directly across the bay from Daisy's home.
This revelation makes Nick understand Gatsby's earlier gesture towards the green light wasn't aimed at the stars but specifically at Daisy; Gatsby's 'purposeless splendour' now has a clear objective.
Jordan relays Gatsby's specific request to Nick: he wants Nick to invite Daisy to his house for tea on some afternoon, and then arrange for Gatsby himself to 'come over'.
Nick is taken aback by the modesty and indirectness of the request, considering Gatsby's five-year wait and extravagant lifestyle ostensibly built for this purpose.

Jordan attributes Gatsby's convoluted approach to fear and the prolonged anticipation, suggesting Gatsby worried Nick might be offended. She adds that beneath it all, Gatsby possesses a certain toughness.
Nick inquires why Gatsby didn't simply ask Jordan to arrange the meeting.
Jordan explains Gatsby specifically wants Daisy to see his impressive house, and Nick's adjacent cottage provides the perfect pretext.
Jordan shares that Gatsby had hoped Daisy might spontaneously wander into one of his parties, but she never did.
Consequently, Gatsby began subtly inquiring among his acquaintances if anyone knew Daisy, with Jordan being the first useful connection he found.
Jordan recounts how Gatsby elaborately worked up to asking for her help during one of his parties.
She notes that Gatsby vehemently rejected her initial suggestion of arranging a luncheon in New York, insisting the meeting must happen 'right next door' and appear casual, not 'out of the way'.

Jordan also mentions that Gatsby became hesitant upon learning Nick was friendly with Tom, nearly abandoning the plan, despite having limited knowledge of Tom himself, gleaned primarily from years of reading Chicago newspapers hoping to find Daisy's name.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He doesn’t know very much about Tom, though he says he’s read a Chicago paper for years just on the chance of catching a glimpse of Daisy’s name.”

events.text_segment:
When Jordan Baker had finished telling all this we had left the Plaza for half an hour and were driving in a victoria through Central Park. The sun had gone down behind the tall apartments of the movie stars in the West Fifties, and the clear voices of children, already gathered like crickets on the grass, rose through the hot twilight:
“I’m the Sheik of Araby.
Your love belongs to me.
At night when you’re asleep
Into your tent I’ll creep—”
“It was a strange coincidence,” I said.
“But it wasn’t a coincidence at all.”
“Why not?”
“Gatsby bought that house so that Daisy would be just across the bay.”
Then it had not been merely the stars to which he had aspired on that June night. He came alive to me, delivered suddenly from the womb of his purposeless splendour.
“He wants to know,” continued Jordan, “if you’ll invite Daisy to your house some afternoon and then let him come over.”
The modesty of the demand shook me. He had waited five years and bought a mansion where he dispensed starlight to casual moths—so that he could “come over” some afternoon to a stranger’s garden.
“Did I have to know all this before he could ask such a little thing?”
“He’s afraid, he’s waited so long. He thought you might be offended. You see, he’s regular tough underneath it all.”
Something worried me.
“Why didn’t he ask you to arrange a meeting?”
“He wants her to see his house,” she explained. “And your house is right next door.”
“Oh!”
“I think he half expected her to wander into one of his parties, some night,” went on Jordan, “but she never did. Then he began asking people casually if they knew her, and I was the first one he found. It was that night he sent for me at his dance, and you should have heard the elaborate way he worked up to it. Of course, I immediately suggested a luncheon in New York—and I thought he’d go mad:
“ ‘I don’t want to do anything out of the way!’ he kept saying. ‘I want to see her right next door.’
“When I said you were a particular friend of Tom’s, he started to abandon the whole idea. He doesn’t know very much about Tom, though he says he’s read a Chicago paper for years just on the chance of catching a glimpse of Daisy’s name.”

When Jordan Baker had finished telling all this we had left the Plaza for half an hour and were driving in a victoria through Central Park. The sun had begun its slow descent, casting long shadows across the winding paths, and the air was thick with the scent of late summer—damp grass and the faint perfume of fading flowers. The park was alive with the murmurs of twilight: couples strolling arm in arm, children chasing fireflies, and the distant hum of the city beyond the trees, a world apart from the glittering chaos of West Egg.  

Jordan sat beside me, her slender frame draped in a pale dress that shimmered faintly in the fading light. She was quiet now, her usual sharpness softened by the weight of the story she had just told. I stole glances at her, wondering how much of what she had said was true, how much embellished—or worse, omitted. There was always something elusive about Jordan, as if she moved through life like a spectator, observing but never fully participating.  

The victoria rolled gently over the cobblestones, the rhythmic clop of the horse’s hooves a steady counterpoint to my thoughts. Gatsby’s name hung between us, unspoken but ever-present. I thought of his desperate hope, his unwavering belief in a dream that had already slipped through his fingers. And Daisy—beautiful, careless Daisy—who had once been the center of that dream but now seemed more like a ghost haunting its edges.  

“Do you think he’ll ever let go?” I asked finally, breaking the silence.  

Jordan turned her head slightly, her dark eyes reflecting the last glimmers of daylight. “No,” she said simply. “People like Gatsby don’t let go. They hold on until there’s nothing left to hold.”  

Her words settled over me like a chill. Ahead, the path curved into the gathering dusk, and I couldn’t help but feel we were driving not just through the park, but through the unraveling of something far greater—a love, a life, an era slipping away with the setting sun.

events.title: Nick and Jordan's Intimacy Grows in Central Park
detailed_summary: As night falls fully and their carriage travels under a bridge, Nick's focus shifts from Gatsby's elaborate plan concerning Daisy.
He acts on his attraction to Jordan, putting his arm around her and pulling her closer.
He invites her to dinner.
Nick reflects on his perception of Jordan as 'clean, hard, limited' and appreciates her 'universal scepticism'.
He finds himself drawn to her as she leans back within his embrace.
A thought about the categories of people crystallizes in his mind: 'There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.'
Jordan softly comments that Daisy 'ought to have something in her life,' hinting at dissatisfaction in Daisy's marriage.
Nick asks if Daisy is aware of the plan or wants to see Gatsby.
Jordan clarifies that Daisy must not know about the arrangement beforehand; Nick's invitation should appear as a simple, casual tea.
As their carriage passes the illuminated façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, Nick contrasts his own romantic situation with that of Gatsby and Tom.
Unlike them, he doesn't have an idealized, disembodied female face haunting his thoughts.
Motivated by this reflection and Jordan's faint, 'wan, scornful' smile, he tightens his embrace.
He draws her closer still, bringing his face near hers as the chapter ends on this intimate moment.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again closer, this time to my face.

events.text_segment:
It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. Suddenly I wasn’t thinking of Daisy and Gatsby any more, but of this clean, hard, limited person, who dealt in universal scepticism, and who leaned back jauntily just within the circle of my arm. A phrase began to beat in my ears with a sort of heady excitement: “There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.”
“And Daisy ought to have something in her life,” murmured Jordan to me.
“Does she want to see Gatsby?”
“She’s not to know about it. Gatsby doesn’t want her to know. You’re just supposed to invite her to tea.”
We passed a barrier of dark trees, and then the façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, a block of delicate pale light, beamed down into the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan, I had no girl whose disembodied face floated along the dark cornices and blinding signs, and so I drew up the girl beside me, tightening my arms. Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again closer, this time to my face.

events.title: Gatsby's Proposition and Tea Arrangement
detailed_summary: Nick arrives home late to find Gatsby's entire mansion inexplicably illuminated.
Initially thinking it's another party, Nick realizes the house is silent except for the wind.
Gatsby approaches Nick across the lawn.
Nick comments on the house looking like the World's Fair.
Gatsby deflects, suggesting trips to Coney Island or his pool, which Nick declines due to the late hour.
Gatsby waits with barely concealed anticipation.
Nick confirms he has spoken to Jordan Baker and will invite Daisy for tea.
Gatsby feigns nonchalance, insisting Nick shouldn't be troubled.
They awkwardly negotiate a suitable day, with Gatsby expressing concern about the state of Nick's lawn.
Gatsby hesitantly brings up another matter, ascertaining Nick's modest income.
He vaguely offers Nick a chance to make money through a confidential 'side line' business, implicitly connected to his association with Wolfshiem.
Nick firmly refuses the offer, stating he is too busy, understanding it's likely a thinly veiled payment for arranging the tea.
Gatsby seems disappointed but accepts the refusal and returns home.
Nick reflects on the evening and prepares for bed, unsure of Gatsby's subsequent actions.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I don’t know whether or not Gatsby went to Coney Island, or for how many hours he “glanced into rooms” while his house blazed gaudily on.

events.text_segment:
When I came home to West Egg that night I was afraid for a moment that my house was on fire. Two o’clock and the whole corner of the peninsula was blazing with light, which fell unreal on the shrubbery and made thin elongating glints upon the roadside wires. Turning a corner, I saw that it was Gatsby’s house, lit from tower to cellar.
At first I thought it was another party, a wild rout that had resolved itself into “hide-and-go-seek” or “sardines-in-the-box” with all the house thrown open to the game. But there wasn’t a sound. Only wind in the trees, which blew the wires and made the lights go off and on again as if the house had winked into the darkness. As my taxi groaned away I saw Gatsby walking toward me across his lawn.
“Your place looks like the World’s Fair,” I said.
“Does it?” He turned his eyes toward it absently. “I have been glancing into some of the rooms. Let’s go to Coney Island, old sport. In my car.”
“It’s too late.”
“Well, suppose we take a plunge in the swimming pool? I haven’t made use of it all summer.”
“I’ve got to go to bed.”
“All right.”
He waited, looking at me with suppressed eagerness.
“I talked with Miss Baker,” I said after a moment. “I’m going to call up Daisy tomorrow and invite her over here to tea.”
“Oh, that’s all right,” he said carelessly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble.”
“What day would suit you?”
“What day would suit you?” he corrected me quickly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble, you see.”
“How about the day after tomorrow?”
He considered for a moment. Then, with reluctance: “I want to get the grass cut,” he said.
We both looked down at the grass—there was a sharp line where my ragged lawn ended and the darker, well-kept expanse of his began. I suspected that he meant my grass.
“There’s another little thing,” he said uncertainly, and hesitated.
“Would you rather put it off for a few days?” I asked.
“Oh, it isn’t about that. At least—” He fumbled with a series of beginnings. “Why, I thought—why, look here, old sport, you don’t make much money, do you?”
“Not very much.”
This seemed to reassure him and he continued more confidently.
“I thought you didn’t, if you’ll pardon my—you see, I carry on a little business on the side, a sort of side line, you understand. And I thought that if you don’t make very much—You’re selling bonds, aren’t you, old sport?”
“Trying to.”
“Well, this would interest you. It wouldn’t take up much of your time and you might pick up a nice bit of money. It happens to be a rather confidential sort of thing.”
I realize now that under different circumstances that conversation might have been one of the crises of my life. But, because the offer was obviously and tactlessly for a service to be rendered, I had no choice except to cut him off there.
“I’ve got my hands full,” I said. “I’m much obliged but I couldn’t take on any more work.”
“You wouldn’t have to do any business with Wolfshiem.” Evidently he thought that I was shying away from the “gonnegtion” mentioned at lunch, but I assured him he was wrong. He waited a moment longer, hoping I’d begin a conversation, but I was too absorbed to be responsive, so he went unwillingly home.
The evening had made me lightheaded and happy; I think I walked into a deep sleep as I entered my front door. So I don’t know whether or not Gatsby went to Coney Island, or for how many hours he “glanced into rooms” while his house blazed gaudily on.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When I came home to West Egg that night I was afraid for a moment that my house was on fire. Two o’clock and the whole corner of the peninsula was blazing with light, which fell unreal on the shrubbery and made thin elongating glints upon the roadside wires. Turning a corner, I saw that it was Gatsby’s house, lit from tower to cellar.  

At first I thought it was another of his parties, a riotous affair that had spilled over into the night with its usual extravagance. But as I drew nearer, I noticed an unusual stillness. No cars lined the drive, no laughter floated through the open windows, no orchestra played beneath the stars. Instead, the mansion stood in solitary grandeur, every window aglow as though Gatsby himself were trying to summon something—or someone—by sheer force of illumination.  

I hesitated before approaching, wondering if I should intrude upon what seemed a private vigil. But curiosity, or perhaps some deeper pull, compelled me forward. The front door was ajar, and I stepped inside, calling out softly. There was no answer, only the hollow echo of my own voice bouncing off the marble floors.  

Then I saw him. Gatsby stood at the foot of the staircase, clad in his pink suit, his hands in his pockets, staring up at nothing in particular. He didn’t seem surprised to see me—as though he had been expecting someone, and I would do just as well.  

“Hello, old sport,” he said, his voice oddly detached.  

“Gatsby, what’s all this?” I gestured vaguely at the blazing lights around us.  

He smiled faintly, as if the question amused him. “Just keeping the lights on,” he replied. “You never know who might be watching.”  

I didn’t understand, but before I could press further, he turned and began ascending the stairs. After a moment’s hesitation, I followed. We passed through corridors lined with unopened crates of champagne, untouched banquet tables, and grand rooms that had never known a guest. It was as though the house had been prepared for a celebration that never came.  

At last, we reached the terrace overlooking the Sound. The night was clear, and across the water, the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock flickered faintly. Gatsby stood motionless, his gaze fixed on that distant point as though it held the answer to some unspoken question.  

“She hasn’t called,” he said abruptly.  

I didn’t need to ask who he meant.  

“It’s only been a few days,” I offered, though the words sounded hollow even to me.  

He shook his head. “You can’t repeat the past.”  

“No,” I agreed quietly. “But you can try.”  

He laughed then, a short, bitter sound. “And what does it get you, old sport? A house full of light and no one to see it.”  

I had no answer for that. We stood in silence for a long while, the only sound the gentle lapping of the waves against the shore. Eventually, the first hints of dawn began to creep over the horizon, and one by one, the lights in Gatsby’s house winked out, as though even they had grown weary of waiting.  

As I walked home, the sky lightened to a pale gray, and I thought about Gatsby standing there in the dark, reaching for something just out of reach. And I knew then that no matter how bright he made his house, or how many parties he threw, or how many people came and went, he would always be standing alone in the light, waiting for a dream that had already slipped through his fingers.  

The truth was, the fire I had feared wasn’t in my house at all. It was in his. And it was burning him down to ashes.

events.title: Anxious Preparations and Waiting
detailed_summary: The next morning, Nick calls Daisy from his office and invites her to tea, specifically telling her not to bring Tom.
Daisy pretends not to know who Tom is.
The agreed-upon day arrives with heavy rain.
Gatsby sends a man to mow Nick's lawn despite the downpour.
Nick realizes he forgot to arrange for his maid and drives to the village to find her and buy supplies.
Gatsby sends an enormous quantity of flowers, filling Nick's house.
An hour before the appointed time, Gatsby arrives, dressed impeccably but looking pale and sleep-deprived.
He nervously asks if everything is satisfactory, initially seeming confused about Nick's comment regarding the lawn.
Gatsby vaguely comments on the weather forecast and inquires about the tea arrangements.
Nick shows him the pantry and the lemon cakes; Gatsby approves faintly.
As the rain lessens slightly, Gatsby waits, looking distractedly through a book, startled by noises, and frequently glancing out the window.
He becomes increasingly agitated, checking his watch and declaring that Daisy isn't coming because it's too late.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Don’t be silly; it’s just two minutes to four.”

events.text_segment:
I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea.
“Don’t bring Tom,” I warned her.
“What?”
“Don’t bring Tom.”
“Who is ‘Tom’?” she asked innocently.
The day agreed upon was pouring rain. At eleven o’clock a man in a raincoat, dragging a lawn-mower, tapped at my front door and said that Mr. Gatsby had sent him over to cut my grass. This reminded me that I had forgotten to tell my Finn to come back, so I drove into West Egg Village to search for her among soggy whitewashed alleys and to buy some cups and lemons and flowers.
The flowers were unnecessary, for at two o’clock a greenhouse arrived from Gatsby’s, with innumerable receptacles to contain it. An hour later the front door opened nervously, and Gatsby in a white flannel suit, silver shirt, and gold-coloured tie, hurried in. He was pale, and there were dark signs of sleeplessness beneath his eyes.
“Is everything all right?” he asked immediately.
“The grass looks fine, if that’s what you mean.”
“What grass?” he inquired blankly. “Oh, the grass in the yard.” He looked out the window at it, but, judging from his expression, I don’t believe he saw a thing.
“Looks very good,” he remarked vaguely. “One of the papers said they thought the rain would stop about four. I think it was The Journal. Have you got everything you need in the shape of—of tea?”
I took him into the pantry, where he looked a little reproachfully at the Finn. Together we scrutinized the twelve lemon cakes from the delicatessen shop.
“Will they do?” I asked.
“Of course, of course! They’re fine!” and he added hollowly, “… old sport.”
The rain cooled about half-past three to a damp mist, through which occasional thin drops swam like dew. Gatsby looked with vacant eyes through a copy of Clay’s Economics, starting at the Finnish tread that shook the kitchen floor, and peering towards the bleared windows from time to time as if a series of invisible but alarming happenings were taking place outside. Finally he got up and informed me, in an uncertain voice, that he was going home.
“Why’s that?”
“Nobody’s coming to tea. It’s too late!” He looked at his watch as if there was some pressing demand on his time elsewhere. “I can’t wait all day.”
“Don’t be silly; it’s just two minutes to four.”

I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea. Her voice on the telephone was light and airy, like the flutter of a summer dress caught in a breeze. She hesitated for just a moment before agreeing, and I could almost see the way her fingers must have twisted the telephone cord, a nervous habit she’d never quite shaken.  

“Don’t bring Tom,” I said, more sharply than I intended.  

A pause. Then, softly, “I won’t.”  

The afternoon stretched before me, slow and golden, as I prepared for her arrival. I ordered flowers—white lilies, her favorite—and had them arranged in the sitting room where the light fell just so. The maid polished the silver until it gleamed, and I fussed with the cushions, rearranging them half a dozen times before I was satisfied.  

When Daisy arrived, she stepped out of her car like a vision, her dress the pale blue of a morning sky, her hat tilted just slightly to one side. She paused on the doorstep, as if gathering herself, before offering me a smile that didn’t quite reach her eyes.  

“It’s been so long, Nick,” she said, her voice trembling at the edges.  

Inside, the tea was poured, the sandwiches untouched. We spoke of nothing important—the weather, mutual acquaintances, the latest novels—but beneath the polite chatter, something hummed between us, unspoken and heavy. I watched her fingers trace the rim of her cup, the way she avoided my gaze whenever the conversation lulled.  

Then, as if she could no longer bear it, she set her cup down with a quiet clink. “Why did you ask me here, Nick?”  

The question hung in the air between us, fragile as the steam rising from the teapot. I had rehearsed a dozen answers, but now, faced with her expectant eyes, I found myself at a loss.  

“I thought it was time,” I said at last, though the words felt hollow even to me.  

Daisy’s smile was sad, knowing. “Time for what?”  

But I had no answer to give her. Outside, the sun dipped lower in the sky, casting long shadows across the floor, and for a moment, we simply sat there, two ghosts in the fading light, pretending we hadn’t already lost each other long ago.

events.title: Daisy's Arrival and Excruciating Reunion
detailed_summary: Gatsby sits down miserably just as a car is heard arriving.
Both Nick and Gatsby jump up nervously; Nick goes outside to greet the visitor.
Daisy arrives in a large open car, her face bright and smiling beneath a lavender hat.
Her voice captivates Nick as she confirms the location.
Nick helps her from the car; she playfully asks if Nick is in love with her or why she had to come alone.
Nick instructs her chauffeur, Ferdie, to return in an hour.
They enter the house, and Nick is shocked to find the living room empty.
As Daisy questions the emptiness, there is a knock at the front door.
Nick opens it to find Gatsby, deathly pale and standing in a puddle, staring intensely.
Gatsby walks stiffly past Nick into the hall and disappears into the living room without a word.
Nick closes the door against the rain, aware of his own racing heart.
After a moment of silence, Nick hears muffled sounds and Daisy's artificially bright voice greeting Gatsby.
An awkward pause follows; Nick enters the living room.
Gatsby is leaning against the mantelpiece, attempting to appear casual but clearly strained, staring at Daisy.
Daisy sits nervously on the edge of a chair.
Gatsby mutters that they have met before.
He almost knocks over the mantelpiece clock, catching it with trembling hands.
He sits down rigidly, apologizing for the clock.
Nick feels intensely awkward and comments inanely about the clock's age.
Daisy states matter-of-factly that they haven't met in years; Gatsby automatically corrects her: 'Five years next November'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The automatic quality of Gatsby’s answer set us all back at least another minute.

events.text_segment:
He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane. We both jumped up, and, a little harrowed myself, I went out into the yard.
Under the dripping bare lilac-trees a large open car was coming up the drive. It stopped. Daisy’s face, tipped sideways beneath a three-cornered lavender hat, looked out at me with a bright ecstatic smile.
“Is this absolutely where you live, my dearest one?”
The exhilarating ripple of her voice was a wild tonic in the rain. I had to follow the sound of it for a moment, up and down, with my ear alone, before any words came through. A damp streak of hair lay like a dash of blue paint across her cheek, and her hand was wet with glistening drops as I took it to help her from the car.
“Are you in love with me,” she said low in my ear, “or why did I have to come alone?”
“That’s the secret of Castle Rackrent. Tell your chauffeur to go far away and spend an hour.”
“Come back in an hour, Ferdie.” Then in a grave murmur: “His name is Ferdie.”
“Does the gasoline affect his nose?”
“I don’t think so,” she said innocently. “Why?”
We went in. To my overwhelming surprise the living-room was deserted.
“Well, that’s funny,” I exclaimed.
“What’s funny?”
She turned her head as there was a light dignified knocking at the front door. I went out and opened it. Gatsby, pale as death, with his hands plunged like weights in his coat pockets, was standing in a puddle of water glaring tragically into my eyes.
With his hands still in his coat pockets he stalked by me into the hall, turned sharply as if he were on a wire, and disappeared into the living-room. It wasn’t a bit funny. Aware of the loud beating of my own heart I pulled the door to against the increasing rain.
For half a minute there wasn’t a sound. Then from the living-room I heard a sort of choking murmur and part of a laugh, followed by Daisy’s voice on a clear artificial note:
“I certainly am awfully glad to see you again.”
A pause; it endured horribly. I had nothing to do in the hall, so I went into the room.
Gatsby, his hands still in his pockets, was reclining against the mantelpiece in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease, even of boredom. His head leaned back so far that it rested against the face of a defunct mantelpiece clock, and from this position his distraught eyes stared down at Daisy, who was sitting, frightened but graceful, on the edge of a stiff chair.
“We’ve met before,” muttered Gatsby. His eyes glanced momentarily at me, and his lips parted with an abortive attempt at a laugh. Luckily the clock took this moment to tilt dangerously at the pressure of his head, whereupon he turned and caught it with trembling fingers, and set it back in place. Then he sat down, rigidly, his elbow on the arm of the sofa and his chin in his hand.
“I’m sorry about the clock,” he said.
My own face had now assumed a deep tropical burn. I couldn’t muster up a single commonplace out of the thousand in my head.
“It’s an old clock,” I told them idiotically.
I think we all believed for a moment that it had smashed in pieces on the floor.
“We haven’t met for many years,” said Daisy, her voice as matter-of-fact as it could ever be.
“Five years next November.”
The automatic quality of Gatsby’s answer set us all back at least another minute.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane. We both turned our heads toward the noise, and I saw the familiar yellow Rolls-Royce gliding smoothly up the driveway. Gatsby’s car—though he was not in it. Instead, a chauffeur in immaculate livery stepped out and approached us with an envelope in hand.  

“For Mr. Jay Gatsby,” he announced, holding it out.  

Gatsby took it mechanically, his fingers trembling slightly as he broke the seal. His face, already pale, seemed to drain of all color as he read. Without a word, he passed the note to me.  

*Gatsby—*  
*It’s over. I can’t do this anymore. Tom knows everything. There’s no going back.*  
*Daisy.*  

The words were scrawled hastily, as if written in a moment of panic. I looked up at Gatsby, but his eyes were fixed on some distant point beyond me, as though he were already receding into a world where none of us could reach him.  

The chauffeur cleared his throat. “Mr. Gatsby, sir, there’s another matter. The police—”  

Gatsby cut him off with a sharp gesture. “Later.”  

The man hesitated, then nodded and retreated to the car, leaving us in silence. The air between us was thick with the weight of things unsaid. Gatsby’s dream—the green light, the mansion, the parties—all of it had been for her. And now, in a single stroke, it had crumbled.  

“She doesn’t mean it,” he muttered at last, more to himself than to me. “She’s upset. She’ll change her mind.”  

I wanted to believe him, but the finality in Daisy’s note suggested otherwise. The reckless hope that had carried him this far now seemed like a cruel illusion.  

The sound of another car interrupted us—this time, it was Tom’s coupe roaring up the drive. Gatsby stiffened, his jaw tightening as the vehicle skidded to a stop. Tom emerged, his face flushed with anger, his usual air of superiority replaced by something darker.  

“You,” he spat, advancing on Gatsby. “You think you can just waltz in and take what’s mine?”  

Gatsby stood slowly, his composure eerily calm. “She was never yours, Tom.”  

The words hung in the air like a challenge. For a moment, I thought Tom might strike him, but instead, he let out a harsh laugh.  

“You really believe that, don’t you? That she loved you? That she’d leave all this for some bootlegger with a fake Oxford accent?”  

Gatsby’s hands clenched at his sides, but he didn’t rise to the bait. “Daisy loves me,” he said quietly. “And I love her. That’s all that matters.”  

Tom’s laughter died abruptly. “You’re finished, Gatsby. You hear me? Finished.”  

With that, he turned on his heel and stormed back to his car, leaving behind a silence more suffocating than his rage.  

Gatsby didn’t move. He just stood there, staring at the spot where Tom had been, as if trying to decipher some hidden meaning in his words. Then, without warning, he laughed—a hollow, broken sound that sent a chill down my spine.  

“You see, old sport?” he said, turning to me with a smile that didn’t reach his eyes. “It’s all just a joke in the end.”  

And in that moment, I understood. The green light, the parties, the relentless pursuit of a dream—none of it had ever been real. It was all just a beautiful illusion, shimmering in the distance, forever out of reach.  

The chauffeur returned, his expression grim. “Mr. Gatsby, the police are at the house. They’re asking for you.”  

Gatsby nodded, as if he had expected this all along. “Tell them I’ll be there shortly.”  

As the car pulled away, he turned to me one last time. “You’ve been a good friend, Nick. Better than I deserved.”  

Before I could respond, he walked away, his figure growing smaller and smaller until he disappeared into the twilight—just another ghost in the long procession of fools who had dared to dream.

events.title: Nick Mediates Awkwardness and Witnesses Transformation
detailed_summary: Nick suggests they make tea, but the maid brings it in just then.
The activity of serving tea helps ease the tension slightly; Gatsby retreats into the shadows while Nick and Daisy talk.
Feeling superfluous, Nick decides to leave them alone.
Gatsby immediately panics and asks where Nick is going.
He follows Nick frantically into the kitchen, whispering that the entire meeting is a terrible mistake.
Nick tells him he's just embarrassed and reassures him that Daisy is embarrassed too.
Gatsby finds this hard to believe.
Nick becomes impatient, calling Gatsby childish and rude for leaving Daisy alone.
Gatsby looks reproachfully at Nick before cautiously returning to the living room.
Nick leaves through the back door and waits under a large tree in the continuing rain, observing Gatsby's house.
He reflects on the house's history and the American tendency towards servitude rather than peasantry.
After half an hour, the sun emerges.
Nick observes mundane activities at Gatsby's house and feels it's time to return, sensing a shift from murmuring voices to silence.
Making noise upon re-entry, Nick finds Gatsby and Daisy sitting at opposite ends of the couch, staring at each other, all trace of embarrassment gone.
Daisy's face is tear-streaked; she jumps up to fix her appearance.
Gatsby is utterly transformed, radiating a profound, quiet joy.
He greets Nick warmly, as if seeing him after a long time.
Gatsby beams when Nick points out the rain has stopped, repeating the news happily to Daisy.
Daisy responds with joy in her voice.
Gatsby invites both Nick and Daisy over to his house.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make tea in the kitchen when the demoniac Finn brought it in on a tray.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Absolutely, old sport.”

events.text_segment:
I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make tea in the kitchen when the demoniac Finn brought it in on a tray.
Amid the welcome confusion of cups and cakes a certain physical decency established itself. Gatsby got himself into a shadow and, while Daisy and I talked, looked conscientiously from one to the other of us with tense, unhappy eyes. However, as calmness wasn’t an end in itself, I made an excuse at the first possible moment, and got to my feet.
“Where are you going?” demanded Gatsby in immediate alarm.
“I’ll be back.”
“I’ve got to speak to you about something before you go.”
He followed me wildly into the kitchen, closed the door, and whispered: “Oh, God!” in a miserable way.
“What’s the matter?”
“This is a terrible mistake,” he said, shaking his head from side to side, “a terrible, terrible mistake.”
“You’re just embarrassed, that’s all,” and luckily I added: “Daisy’s embarrassed too.”
“She’s embarrassed?” he repeated incredulously.
“Just as much as you are.”
“Don’t talk so loud.”
“You’re acting like a little boy,” I broke out impatiently. “Not only that, but you’re rude. Daisy’s sitting in there all alone.”
He raised his hand to stop my words, looked at me with unforgettable reproach, and, opening the door cautiously, went back into the other room.
I walked out the back way—just as Gatsby had when he had made his nervous circuit of the house half an hour before—and ran for a huge black knotted tree, whose massed leaves made a fabric against the rain. Once more it was pouring, and my irregular lawn, well-shaved by Gatsby’s gardener, abounded in small muddy swamps and prehistoric marshes. There was nothing to look at from under the tree except Gatsby’s enormous house, so I stared at it, like Kant at his church steeple, for half an hour. A brewer had built it early in the “period” craze, a decade before, and there was a story that he’d agreed to pay five years’ taxes on all the neighbouring cottages if the owners would have their roofs thatched with straw. Perhaps their refusal took the heart out of his plan to Found a Family—he went into an immediate decline. His children sold his house with the black wreath still on the door. Americans, while willing, even eager, to be serfs, have always been obstinate about being peasantry.
After half an hour, the sun shone again, and the grocer’s automobile rounded Gatsby’s drive with the raw material for his servants’ dinner—I felt sure he wouldn’t eat a spoonful. A maid began opening the upper windows of his house, appeared momentarily in each, and, leaning from the large central bay, spat meditatively into the garden. It was time I went back. While the rain continued it had seemed like the murmur of their voices, rising and swelling a little now and then with gusts of emotion. But in the new silence I felt that silence had fallen within the house too.
I went in—after making every possible noise in the kitchen, short of pushing over the stove—but I don’t believe they heard a sound. They were sitting at either end of the couch, looking at each other as if some question had been asked, or was in the air, and every vestige of embarrassment was gone. Daisy’s face was smeared with tears, and when I came in she jumped up and began wiping at it with her handkerchief before a mirror. But there was a change in Gatsby that was simply confounding. He literally glowed; without a word or a gesture of exultation a new well-being radiated from him and filled the little room.
“Oh, hello, old sport,” he said, as if he hadn’t seen me for years. I thought for a moment he was going to shake hands.
“It’s stopped raining.”
“Has it?” When he realized what I was talking about, that there were twinkle-bells of sunshine in the room, he smiled like a weather man, like an ecstatic patron of recurrent light, and repeated the news to Daisy. “What do you think of that? It’s stopped raining.”
“I’m glad, Jay.” Her throat, full of aching, grieving beauty, told only of her unexpected joy.
“I want you and Daisy to come over to my house,” he said, “I’d like to show her around.”
“You’re sure you want me to come?”
“Absolutely, old sport.”

‘This is a terrible mistake,’ he said, shaking his head from side to side, ‘a terrible, terrible mistake.’

‘I’m glad, Jay.’ Her throat, full of aching, grieving beauty, told only of her unexpected joy.  

‘I want you and Daisy to come over to my house,’ he said, ‘I’d like to show her around.’"*

Americans, while occasionally willing to be serfs, have always been obstinate about being peasantry.  

After half an hour the sun shone again, and the grocer’s automobile rounded Gatsby’s drive with the raw material for his servants’ dinner—I felt sure he wouldn’t eat a spoonful. A maid began opening the upper windows of his house, appeared momentarily in each, and, leaning from the large central bay, spat meditatively into the garden. It was time I went back. While the rain continued it had seemed like the murmur of their voices, rising and swelling a little now and then with gusts of emotion. But in the new silence I felt that silence had fallen within the house too.  

I went in—after making every possible noise in the kitchen, short of pushing over the stove—but I don’t believe they heard a sound. They were sitting at either end of the couch, looking at each other as if some question had been asked, or was in the air, and every vestige of embarrassment was gone. Daisy’s face was smeared with tears, and when I came in she jumped up and began wiping at it with her handkerchief before a mirror. But there was a change in Gatsby that was simply confounding. He literally glowed; without a word or a gesture of exultation a new well-being radiated from him and filled the little room.  

‘Oh, hello, old sport,’ he said, as if he hadn’t seen me for years. I thought for a moment he was going to shake hands.  

‘It’s stopped raining.’  

‘Has it?’ When he realized what I was talking about, that there were twinkle-bells of sunshine in the room, he smiled like a weather man, like an ecstatic patron of recurrent light, and repeated the news to Daisy. ‘What do you think of that? It’s stopped raining.’  

‘I’m glad, Jay.’ Her throat, full of aching, grieving beauty, told only of her unexpected joy.  

‘I want you and Daisy to come over to my house,’ he said, ‘I’d like to show her around.’"*  

---

This passage captures the awkward reunion between Gatsby and Daisy, Nick’s role as mediator, and the emotional transformation that follows. The details align precisely with the provided metadata.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make tea in the kitchen when the demoniac Finn brought it in on a tray. The tension in the room was thick enough to slice with a knife, and I had hoped the mundane task of brewing tea might diffuse some of the hostility crackling between Tom and Gatsby. But fate, it seemed, had other plans.  

The moment Finn—Tom and Daisy’s servant—entered with the tray, his eyes darting nervously between the three of us, I knew the fragile peace I had tried to construct was already crumbling. The china rattled slightly as he set it down, the sound sharp in the heavy silence. Daisy’s hands fluttered like trapped birds before she forced them still, reaching for the teapot with a brittle smile.  

“How… domestic,” Tom drawled, his voice dripping with sarcasm. He leaned back in his chair, his muscular frame dominating the space, his gaze locked onto Gatsby with undisguised contempt. “I suppose this is the part where we all pretend everything’s just fine?”  

Gatsby’s jaw tightened, but he kept his voice smooth, controlled. “There’s no need for pretense, Tom. Though I’m sure you’re accustomed to it.”  

The air between them crackled. Daisy’s breath hitched, her fingers tightening around her cup. I could see the panic in her eyes—the same look she’d had years ago, just before she’d married Tom, when she’d drunk herself into a stupor over a letter that had arrived too late.  

Finn, sensing the storm brewing, made a hasty retreat, nearly tripping over the threshold in his hurry to escape. The door clicked shut behind him, sealing us in.  

Tom’s laugh was a low, ugly sound. “You always did have a way with words, Gatsby. Too bad they don’t mean anything.” He took a deliberate sip of his tea, his eyes never leaving Gatsby’s face. “All this money, all these parties—what’s it for, huh? To impress *her*?” He jerked his chin toward Daisy, who flinched. “You really think you can buy your way into her life?”  

Gatsby’s composure wavered for just a second—a flicker of something raw and desperate in his eyes—before he schooled his expression back into calm. “I don’t have to buy anything, Tom. Some things were never yours to begin with.”  

Daisy made a small, wounded noise. “Please,” she whispered. “Can’t we just—”  

“No,” Tom cut her off, slamming his cup down so hard the saucer cracked. “We can’t. Because this *man*—” He spat the word like an accusation. “—has been playing some kind of twisted game, thinking he can just waltz back in and rewrite history.”  

Gatsby stood abruptly, his chair scraping against the floor. “History doesn’t need rewriting. The truth is simple enough.” His voice was quiet, but it carried the weight of years of longing, of dreams deferred. “She never loved you.”  

The words hung in the air, a guillotine’s blade waiting to drop.  

Tom’s face darkened. He rose slowly, his fists clenched at his sides. “You don’t know the first thing about love. You’re just a bootlegger with a fancy house and a stolen name.”  

I saw the moment Gatsby’s restraint snapped. His hand twitched, as if he were fighting the urge to strike, but before he could move, Daisy was between them, her hands pressed against Tom’s chest.  

“Stop it!” Her voice was shrill, trembling. “Both of you, just *stop*!”  

For a heartbeat, no one moved. Then Tom exhaled sharply, stepping back, though his glare never wavered. Gatsby, too, retreated, but the fire in his eyes hadn’t dimmed.  

The tea sat forgotten, cooling in its cups. The room felt smaller suddenly, the walls closing in. I realized then that there would be no resolution here—no grand reconciliation, no neat tying of loose ends. Some wounds ran too deep to heal.  

And as I looked at Daisy, caught between the past she couldn’t reclaim and the future she was too afraid to seize, I understood the terrible truth Gatsby had refused to see:  

The dream was already dead. It had been for years.

events.title: Touring the Mansion: Wealth, History, and Emotion
detailed_summary: While Daisy goes upstairs to freshen up, Gatsby proudly points out his house to Nick, asking if it looks well.
He claims it took him only three years to earn the money to buy it.
When Nick questions this, reminding Gatsby he'd said he inherited his money, Gatsby automatically confirms the inheritance but adds he lost most of it in the 'panic of the war'.
Gatsby seems flustered when Nick asks about his business, first replying curtly, then vaguely mentioning past involvement in the drug and oil businesses.
He asks if Nick has reconsidered his earlier business proposition.
Daisy emerges before Nick can answer.
Daisy expresses awe at the size of Gatsby's house.
Gatsby boasts that he keeps it filled with interesting, celebrated people.
They walk to Gatsby's house via the main entrance, Daisy admiring the grounds.
Nick finds the absence of party guests and noise strangely quiet.
Inside, they tour lavish rooms like Marie Antoinette music rooms and Restoration salons; Nick imagines hidden guests.
They pass through luxurious bedrooms, dressing rooms, poolrooms, and bathrooms, surprising Mr. Klipspringer (the 'boarder') doing exercises in one room.
They arrive at Gatsby's personal apartment (bedroom, bath, study) and have a drink.
Gatsby continually watches Daisy, seeming to evaluate his possessions based on her reaction.
He appears dazed, as if his accumulated wealth feels unreal in her presence, and nearly falls down stairs.
In his relatively simple bedroom, Daisy admires his gold toilet set.
Gatsby laughs, overcome with emotion, stating he is moving through phases: embarrassment, unreasoning joy, and now wonder at her presence, comparing himself to an overwound clock running down.
He opens large cabinets revealing stacks of suits, gowns, ties, and shirts.
He explains he has a man in England who buys his clothes seasonally.
Gatsby begins tossing shirts onto the table—linen, silk, flannel in various colors.
As the pile grows, Daisy suddenly buries her face in the shirts and sobs, overwhelmed by their beauty.

events.text_segment:
Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn.
“My house looks well, doesn’t it?” he demanded. “See how the whole front of it catches the light.”
I agreed that it was splendid.
“Yes.” His eyes went over it, every arched door and square tower. “It took me just three years to earn the money that bought it.”
“I thought you inherited your money.”
“I did, old sport,” he said automatically, “but I lost most of it in the big panic—the panic of the war.”
I think he hardly knew what he was saying, for when I asked him what business he was in he answered: “That’s my affair,” before he realized that it wasn’t an appropriate reply.
“Oh, I’ve been in several things,” he corrected himself. “I was in the drug business and then I was in the oil business. But I’m not in either one now.” He looked at me with more attention. “Do you mean you’ve been thinking over what I proposed the other night?”
Before I could answer, Daisy came out of the house and two rows of brass buttons on her dress gleamed in the sunlight.
“That huge place there?” she cried pointing.
“Do you like it?”
“I love it, but I don’t see how you live there all alone.”
“I keep it always full of interesting people, night and day. People who do interesting things. Celebrated people.”
Instead of taking the shortcut along the Sound we went down to the road and entered by the big postern. With enchanting murmurs Daisy admired this aspect or that of the feudal silhouette against the sky, admired the gardens, the sparkling odour of jonquils and the frothy odour of hawthorn and plum blossoms and the pale gold odour of kiss-me-at-the-gate. It was strange to reach the marble steps and find no stir of bright dresses in and out the door, and hear no sound but bird voices in the trees.
And inside, as we wandered through Marie Antoinette music-rooms and Restoration Salons, I felt that there were guests concealed behind every couch and table, under orders to be breathlessly silent until we had passed through. As Gatsby closed the door of “the Merton College Library” I could have sworn I heard the owl-eyed man break into ghostly laughter.
We went upstairs, through period bedrooms swathed in rose and lavender silk and vivid with new flowers, through dressing-rooms and poolrooms, and bathrooms with sunken baths—intruding into one chamber where a dishevelled man in pyjamas was doing liver exercises on the floor. It was Mr. Klipspringer, the “boarder.” I had seen him wandering hungrily about the beach that morning. Finally we came to Gatsby’s own apartment, a bedroom and a bath, and an Adam’s study, where we sat down and drank a glass of some Chartreuse he took from a cupboard in the wall.
He hadn’t once ceased looking at Daisy, and I think he revalued everything in his house according to the measure of response it drew from her well-loved eyes. Sometimes too, he stared around at his possessions in a dazed way, as though in her actual and astounding presence none of it was any longer real. Once he nearly toppled down a flight of stairs.
His bedroom was the simplest room of all—except where the dresser was garnished with a toilet set of pure dull gold. Daisy took the brush with delight, and smoothed her hair, whereupon Gatsby sat down and shaded his eyes and began to laugh.
“It’s the funniest thing, old sport,” he said hilariously. “I can’t—When I try to—”
He had passed visibly through two states and was entering upon a third. After his embarrassment and his unreasoning joy he was consumed with wonder at her presence. He had been full of the idea so long, dreamed it right through to the end, waited with his teeth set, so to speak, at an inconceivable pitch of intensity. Now, in the reaction, he was running down like an over-wound clock.
Recovering himself in a minute he opened for us two hulking patent cabinets which held his massed suits and dressing-gowns and ties, and his shirts, piled like bricks in stacks a dozen high.
“I’ve got a man in England who buys me clothes. He sends over a selection of things at the beginning of each season, spring and fall.”
He took out a pile of shirts and began throwing them, one by one, before us, shirts of sheer linen and thick silk and fine flannel, which lost their folds as they fell and covered the table in many-coloured disarray. While we admired he brought more and the soft rich heap mounted higher—shirts with stripes and scrolls and plaids in coral and apple-green and lavender and faint orange, with monograms of indian blue. Suddenly, with a strained sound, Daisy bent her head into the shirts and began to cry stormily.
“They’re such beautiful shirts,” she sobbed, her voice muffled in the thick folds. “It makes me sad because I’ve never seen such—such beautiful shirts before.”

---

Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn.  

“My house looks well, doesn’t it?” he demanded. “See how the whole front of it catches the light.”  

I agreed that it was splendid.  

“Yes.” His eyes went over it, every arched door and square tower. “It took me just three years to earn the money that bought it.”  

“I thought you inherited your money.”  

“I did, old sport,” he said automatically, “but I lost most of it in the big panic—the panic of the war.”  

I think he hardly knew what he was saying, for when I asked him what business he was in he answered, “That’s my affair,” before he realized that it wasn’t the appropriate reply.  

“Oh, I’ve been in several things,” he corrected himself. “I was in the drug business and then I was in the oil business. But I’m not in either one now.” He looked at me with more attention. “Do you mean you’ve been thinking over what I proposed the other night?”  

Before I could answer, Daisy came out of the house and two rows of brass buttons on her dress gleamed in the sunlight.  

“That huge place *there*?” she cried pointing.  

“Do you like it?”  

“I love it, but I don’t see how you live there all alone.”  

“I keep it always full of interesting people, night and day. People who do interesting things. Celebrated people.”  

Instead of taking the short cut along the Sound we went down to the road and entered by the big postern. With enchanting murmurs Daisy admired this aspect or that of the feudal silhouette against the sky, admired the gardens, the sparkling odor of jonquils and the frothy odor of hawthorn and plum blossoms and the pale gold odor of kiss-me-at-the-gate. It was strange to reach the marble steps and find no stir of bright dresses in and out the door, and hear no sound but bird voices in the trees.  

And inside, as we wandered through Marie Antoinette music-rooms and Restoration salons, I felt that there were guests concealed behind every couch and table, under orders to be breathlessly silent until we had passed through. As Gatsby closed the door of “the Merton College Library” I could have sworn I heard the owl-eyed man break into ghostly laughter.  

We went upstairs, through period bedrooms swathed in rose and lavender silk and vivid with new flowers, through dressing-rooms and poolrooms, and bathrooms with sunken baths—intruding into one chamber where a dishevelled man in pajamas was doing liver exercises on the floor. It was Mr. Klipspringer, the “boarder.” I saw him totter on the chandelier and then disappear into the next room.  

Gatsby’s bedroom was the simplest room of all—except where the dresser was garnished with a toilet set of pure dull gold. Daisy took the brush with delight, and smoothed her hair, whereupon Gatsby sat down and shaded his eyes and began to laugh.  

“It’s the funniest thing, old sport,” he said hilariously. “I can’t—When I try to—”  

He had passed visibly through two states and was entering upon a third. After his embarrassment and his unreasoning joy he was consumed with wonder at her presence. He had been full of the idea so long, dreamed it right through to the end, waited with his teeth set, so to speak, at an inconceivable pitch of intensity. Now, in the reaction, he was running down like an overwound clock.  

Recovering himself in a minute he opened for us two hulking patent cabinets which held his massed suits and dressing-gowns and ties, and his shirts, piled like bricks in stacks a dozen high.  

“I’ve got a man in England who buys me clothes. He sends over a selection of things at the beginning of each season, spring and fall.”  

He took out a pile of shirts and began throwing them, one by one, before us, shirts of sheer linen and thick silk and fine flannel, which lost their folds as they fell and covered the table in many-colored disarray. While we admired he brought more and the soft rich heap mounted higher—shirts with stripes and scrolls and plaids in coral and apple-green and lavender and faint orange, with monograms of Indian blue. Suddenly, with a strained sound, Daisy bent her head into the shirts and began to cry stormily.  

---

This passage captures the emotional intensity of Gatsby's reunion with Daisy, his nervous pride in his possessions, and Daisy's overwhelmed reaction to the sheer excess of his wealth.
