LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn. The evening air was thick with the scent of roses and the distant murmur of the bay. Gatsby stood motionless, his hands in his pockets, staring at the darkening sky as if searching for something beyond the stars. I watched him, struck once again by the intensity of his longing, the way his whole being seemed poised on the edge of some invisible precipice.

"You know," I said, breaking the silence, "she was quite taken with the house."  

Gatsby turned to me, his eyes alight with hope. "Was she?"  

"Yes," I replied, though I wasn’t entirely sure. Daisy had been polite, even effusive in her admiration, but there had been something hollow in her exclamations, as though she were performing for an audience. Still, I couldn’t bring myself to dim the eager flame in Gatsby’s expression.  

He exhaled sharply, as if releasing a breath he’d been holding for years. "I knew she would be. I planned it all for her, Nick. Every detail." His voice was low, almost reverent. "The gardens, the marble steps, the chandeliers—all of it. I wanted it to be perfect."  

I nodded, though a pang of unease settled in my chest. There was something unsettling about the way Gatsby spoke of Daisy, as though she were a prize to be won rather than a woman with her own desires. But then, perhaps that was the nature of his dream—so long nurtured in solitude that it had taken on a life of its own, untethered from reality.  

The sound of footsteps on the terrace drew our attention. Daisy emerged, her face freshly powdered, her smile bright but brittle. "Well," she said, clasping her hands together, "what shall we do now?"  

Gatsby stepped forward instantly, as though pulled by an invisible string. "We could go for a drive," he suggested. "The night is perfect for it."  

Daisy hesitated, glancing at me. "Oh, I don’t know—"  

"Please," Gatsby said softly, and there was something in his voice that made even me want to agree.  

Daisy relented with a small laugh. "All right, then. A drive it is."  

Gatsby’s car, that monstrous, cream-colored machine, gleamed under the moonlight like some fantastical beast. He opened the door for Daisy with a flourish, and she slid inside, her dress rustling against the leather. I followed, taking the seat beside her, while Gatsby took the wheel.  

As the engine roared to life, Daisy let out a delighted gasp. "Oh, it’s like flying!"  

Gatsby glanced at her, his smile triumphant. "That’s exactly what I thought the first time I drove it."  

We sped through the warm night, the wind whipping through our hair, the world reduced to a blur of shadows and light. For a moment, it felt as though we had escaped time itself, hurtling toward some unknown destination where nothing mattered but the thrill of the ride.  

But then, as we rounded a curve, a figure stepped into the road—a man, his face pale with shock, his arms raised as if to ward us off. Gatsby swerved violently, the car skidding dangerously before righting itself. My heart pounded in my chest, and beside me, Daisy let out a sharp cry.  

"Did we—did we hit him?" she whispered.  

Gatsby didn’t answer. His knuckles were white on the wheel, his jaw set. The car slowed, then stopped. For a long moment, none of us moved. Then, with a deep breath, Gatsby turned to look at us.  

"It’s nothing," he said firmly. "Just a shadow."  

But I had seen the man’s face, the terror in his eyes. And as we drove on, the magic of the night shattered, I couldn’t shake the feeling that something irrevocable had shifted—that the dream, so carefully constructed, was beginning to fray at the edges.  

Daisy, sensing the tension, reached for Gatsby’s hand. "Let’s go back," she said quietly.  

He nodded, his expression unreadable. And as we turned the car toward home, I wondered if Gatsby, too, felt the first cold whispers of doubt creeping in.

events.title: Reflections, Memories, Music, and Lingering Doubts
detailed_summary: Plans to see the grounds are halted as rain begins again; they look out at the Sound.
Gatsby points across the bay towards Daisy's house, mentioning the green light on her dock.
He remarks on its constant presence.
Daisy puts her arm through his, but Gatsby seems lost in thought, perhaps realizing the light's symbolic meaning has now fundamentally changed.
Nick reflects that the light, once representing the vast distance to Daisy, is now just a light, diminishing Gatsby's 'enchanted objects'.
Nick examines items in the room, noticing a large photo of Dan Cody, whom Gatsby identifies as a deceased former best friend.
There's also a small, defiant photo of a young Gatsby in yachting gear.
Daisy admires the old photo; Gatsby quickly redirects her attention to a collection of news clippings he saved about her.
Gatsby takes a brief, coded phone call related to his business dealings, mentioning a 'small town' and Detroit.
Daisy calls them to the window to admire a break in the clouds revealing pink and gold sky over the sea.
She whispers a desire to put Gatsby in one of the clouds.
Nick tries to leave, but they insist he stay, possibly needing his presence to feel comfortably alone.
Gatsby decides Klipspringer should play the piano.
He fetches the reluctant Klipspringer, now dressed casually.
Klipspringer protests his lack of practice but is urged to play.
Gatsby turns on lights throughout the house and sits with Daisy on a couch in the dimly lit music room while Klipspringer plays 'The Love Nest'.
Klipspringer again complains about his playing but is told sharply by Gatsby to continue.
As Klipspringer plays 'Ain't We Got Fun', Nick observes the weather and the general atmosphere of West Egg.
Nick notices a look of bewilderment return to Gatsby's face.
Nick speculates that even in this moment of reunion, Daisy might inevitably fall short of Gatsby's enormous, idealized vision of her.
He considers the impossibility of reality matching the 'colossal vitality of his illusion'.
Gatsby seems to recompose himself, taking Daisy's hand as she murmurs to him.
Nick concludes that Daisy's captivating voice is the one element that couldn't be 'over-dreamed'.
Feeling forgotten, Nick prepares to leave; Daisy offers her hand, but Gatsby seems completely unaware of Nick.
Nick observes them one last time, seeing them as remote and intensely absorbed in each other, before leaving them alone together in the rain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together.

events.text_segment:
After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound.
“If it wasn’t for the mist we could see your home across the bay,” said Gatsby. “You always have a green light that burns all night at the end of your dock.”
Daisy put her arm through his abruptly, but he seemed absorbed in what he had just said. Possibly it had occurred to him that the colossal significance of that light had now vanished forever. Compared to the great distance that had separated him from Daisy it had seemed very near to her, almost touching her. It had seemed as close as a star to the moon. Now it was again a green light on a dock. His count of enchanted objects had diminished by one.
I began to walk about the room, examining various indefinite objects in the half darkness. A large photograph of an elderly man in yachting costume attracted me, hung on the wall over his desk.
“Who’s this?”
“That? That’s Mr. Dan Cody, old sport.”
The name sounded faintly familiar.
“He’s dead now. He used to be my best friend years ago.”
There was a small picture of Gatsby, also in yachting costume, on the bureau—Gatsby with his head thrown back defiantly—taken apparently when he was about eighteen.
“I adore it,” exclaimed Daisy. “The pompadour! You never told me you had a pompadour—or a yacht.”
“Look at this,” said Gatsby quickly. “Here’s a lot of clippings—about you.”
They stood side by side examining it. I was going to ask to see the rubies when the phone rang, and Gatsby took up the receiver.
“Yes… Well, I can’t talk now… I can’t talk now, old sport… I said a small town… He must know what a small town is… Well, he’s no use to us if Detroit is his idea of a small town…”
He rang off.
“Come here quick!” cried Daisy at the window.
The rain was still falling, but the darkness had parted in the west, and there was a pink and golden billow of foamy clouds above the sea.
“Look at that,” she whispered, and then after a moment: “I’d like to just get one of those pink clouds and put you in it and push you around.”
I tried to go then, but they wouldn’t hear of it; perhaps my presence made them feel more satisfactorily alone.
“I know what we’ll do,” said Gatsby, “we’ll have Klipspringer play the piano.”
He went out of the room calling “Ewing!” and returned in a few minutes accompanied by an embarrassed, slightly worn young man, with shell-rimmed glasses and scanty blond hair. He was now decently clothed in a “sport shirt,” open at the neck, sneakers, and duck trousers of a nebulous hue.
“Did we interrupt your exercise?” inquired Daisy politely.
“I was asleep,” cried Mr. Klipspringer, in a spasm of embarrassment. “That is, I’d been asleep. Then I got up…”
“Klipspringer plays the piano,” said Gatsby, cutting him off. “Don’t you, Ewing, old sport?”
“I don’t play well. I don’t—hardly play at all. I’m all out of prac—”
“We’ll go downstairs,” interrupted Gatsby. He flipped a switch. The grey windows disappeared as the house glowed full of light.
In the music-room Gatsby turned on a solitary lamp beside the piano. He lit Daisy’s cigarette from a trembling match, and sat down with her on a couch far across the room, where there was no light save what the gleaming floor bounced in from the hall.
When Klipspringer had played “The Love Nest” he turned around on the bench and searched unhappily for Gatsby in the gloom.
“I’m all out of practice, you see. I told you I couldn’t play. I’m all out of prac—”
“Don’t talk so much, old sport,” commanded Gatsby. “Play!”
“In the morning,
In the evening,
Ain’t we got fun—”
Outside the wind was loud and there was a faint flow of thunder along the Sound. All the lights were going on in West Egg now; the electric trains, men-carrying, were plunging home through the rain from New York. It was the hour of a profound human change, and excitement was generating on the air.
“One thing’s sure and nothing’s surer
The rich get richer and the poor get—children.
In the meantime,
In between time—”
As I went over to say goodbye I saw that the expression of bewilderment had come back into Gatsby’s face, as though a faint doubt had occurred to him as to the quality of his present happiness. Almost five years! There must have been moments even that afternoon when Daisy tumbled short of his dreams—not through her own fault, but because of the colossal vitality of his illusion. It had gone beyond her, beyond everything. He had thrown himself into it with a creative passion, adding to it all the time, decking it out with every bright feather that drifted his way. No amount of fire or freshness can challenge what a man can store up in his ghostly heart.
As I watched him he adjusted himself a little, visibly. His hand took hold of hers, and as she said something low in his ear he turned toward her with a rush of emotion. I think that voice held him most, with its fluctuating, feverish warmth, because it couldn’t be over-dreamed—that voice was a deathless song.
They had forgotten me, but Daisy glanced up and held out her hand; Gatsby didn’t know me now at all. I looked once more at them and they looked back at me, remotely, possessed by intense life. Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The rain fell in steady sheets, blurring the horizon where the Sound met the sky. Gatsby stood motionless, his hands in his pockets, his gaze fixed on the distant water as if searching for something beyond the gray veil of rain. Nick, Daisy, and Jordan lingered beside him, the silence between them heavy with unspoken thoughts.  

Daisy shivered slightly, though the air was warm. She wrapped her arms around herself, her delicate fingers pressing into the sleeves of her dress. "It’s like the whole world is crying," she murmured, her voice barely audible over the drumming of the rain against the windows.  

Gatsby turned to her, his expression softening. "It’ll pass," he said, with a quiet certainty that seemed to belong to another time, another place—somewhere far removed from this damp, uncertain afternoon.  

Nick watched them, struck by the strange intimacy of the moment. There was something almost theatrical about it, as if they were all playing roles in a scene that had been written long before they’d stepped into it. Jordan, ever observant, caught his eye and gave him a small, knowing smile, as if to say, *Isn’t it fascinating, the way they orbit each other?*  

The rain slackened after a while, though the sky remained stubbornly overcast. Gatsby, ever the host, suggested they move to the library, where a fire had been lit to ward off the damp. As they walked through the grand halls, Nick couldn’t help but marvel at the sheer excess of it all—the towering shelves of unread books, the imported tapestries, the gleaming chandeliers that seemed to hang like frozen constellations. It was as if Gatsby had assembled a museum of wealth, each room a carefully curated exhibit of his success.  

In the library, the fire crackled warmly, casting flickering shadows across the leather-bound volumes. Daisy drifted toward the shelves, running her fingers along the spines with a wistful expression. "Did you read all of these, Jay?" she asked, her voice light, teasing.  

Gatsby hesitated, just for a fraction of a second, before answering. "Of course," he said, but there was something in his tone—a faint defensiveness—that made Nick wonder.  

Jordan, ever perceptive, arched an eyebrow but said nothing. Instead, she settled into one of the deep armchairs, stretching her legs out before her with the easy grace of someone entirely at home in luxury. "You know," she mused, "I’ve always thought libraries are the most romantic rooms in a house. All those stories, all those secrets..."  

Daisy turned to Gatsby, her eyes bright with sudden mischief. "Do you have any secrets, Jay?"  

The question hung in the air, charged with something unspoken. Gatsby’s smile was careful, practiced. "Only the ones worth keeping," he replied.  

Nick felt a pang of something—discomfort, perhaps, or pity. He had seen enough of Gatsby’s world to know that beneath the glittering surface, there were depths that even Daisy, with all her charm, might never fully understand.  

The afternoon wore on, the rain returning intermittently, as if unable to make up its mind. They drifted from room to room, Gatsby leading the way with a quiet pride, pointing out this detail or that treasure—a marble bust from Italy, a collection of rare orchids, a gold-plated clock that had once belonged to a European prince. Each object seemed to carry its own story, its own fragment of the grand illusion Gatsby had built.  

By the time they reached the swimming pool, the rain had stopped entirely, though the sky remained heavy with the promise of more. The water shimmered, unnaturally blue against the muted tones of the garden. Daisy stood at the edge, her reflection wavering on the surface. "It’s like something out of a dream," she said softly.  

Gatsby watched her, his expression unreadable. "That’s the idea," he murmured.  

Nick found himself thinking of the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock—that distant, elusive beacon Gatsby had reached for across the water. Standing here now, surrounded by the tangible proof of Gatsby’s success, it was hard not to wonder if any of it had brought him closer to what he truly wanted.  

As if sensing his thoughts, Gatsby turned to him, his smile faint but genuine. "It’s something, isn’t it?"  

Nick nodded, though he wasn’t entirely sure what he was agreeing to. The house, the pool, the hydroplane waiting in its boathouse—they were all part of the spectacle, the grand performance Gatsby had staged for an audience of one.  

And Daisy, lovely Daisy, stood at the center of it all, her laughter ringing like a bell through the damp air, as if she alone held the key to the dream.  

The rain began again just as they turned to go inside, as though the sky itself were reluctant to let the afternoon end. Gatsby paused at the door, looking back at the pool, the gardens, the gray expanse of the Sound beyond. For a moment, Nick thought he saw something like doubt flicker across his face—but then it was gone, smoothed away by the easy charm that had carried him so far.  

"Tomorrow," Gatsby said, as much to himself as to the rest of them, "the sun will be out again."  

And with that, he led them inside, closing the door on the rain and the gathering twilight, stepping back into the golden world he had made.

events.title: A Reporter's Inquiry and Gatsby's Growing Notoriety
detailed_summary: An inquisitive young reporter from New York appears at Gatsby's residence.
The reporter vaguely asks Gatsby for a statement, having heard his name mentioned in his office.
The reporter's visit, though based on unclear information, reflects Gatsby's increasing notoriety.
Gatsby's fame, fueled by speculation from his party guests, has grown throughout the summer.
Various myths have become associated with Gatsby, including owning an underground pipeline or living in a mobile house-like boat.
The narrator questions the reasons behind James Gatz finding satisfaction in these fantastical rumors.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just why these inventions were a source of satisfaction to James Gatz of North Dakota, isn’t easy to say.

events.text_segment:
About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.
“Anything to say about what?” inquired Gatsby politely.
“Why—any statement to give out.”
It transpired after a confused five minutes that the man had heard Gatsby’s name around his office in a connection which he either wouldn’t reveal or didn’t fully understand. This was his day off and with laudable initiative he had hurried out “to see.”
It was a random shot, and yet the reporter’s instinct was right. Gatsby’s notoriety, spread about by the hundreds who had accepted his hospitality and so become authorities upon his past, had increased all summer until he fell just short of being news. Contemporary legends such as the “underground pipeline to Canada” attached themselves to him, and there was one persistent story that he didn’t live in a house at all, but in a boat that looked like a house and was moved secretly up and down the Long Island shore. Just why these inventions were a source of satisfaction to James Gatz of North Dakota, isn’t easy to say.

This was his day off and with laudable initiative he had hurried out ‘to see.’*  

*It was a random shot, and yet the reporter’s instinct was right. Gatsby’s notoriety, spread about by the hundreds who had accepted his hospitality and so become authorities upon his past, had increased all summer until he fell just short of being news. Contemporary legends such as the ‘underground pipe-line to Canada’ attached themselves to him, and there was one persistent story that he didn’t live in a house at all, but in a boat that looked like a house and was moved secretly up and down the Long Island shore. About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say. Gatsby, caught off guard, hesitated for a moment before offering the young man a drink. The reporter, eager for a scoop, pressed him with questions about his wealth, his parties, and the rumors swirling around him.  

With a faint smile, Gatsby deflected each inquiry with practiced ease, speaking in vague generalities about luck and opportunity. The reporter, undeterred, scribbled notes furiously, piecing together his own version of the enigmatic host. Just as the interview seemed to reach a dead end, Gatsby leaned forward slightly, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper.  

"Tell me," he said, "do people really believe all those stories?"  

The reporter blinked, unsure if he was being mocked. Before he could respond, Gatsby stood, signaling the end of their conversation. "If you want the truth," he said, "come back in a month. I’ll have something worth printing then."  

And with that, the door closed softly behind him.

events.title: The Creation of Jay Gatsby: Name Change and Self-Invention
detailed_summary: The narrator reveals Gatsby's legal name was James Gatz.

This transformation occurred when he saw Dan Cody's yacht anchor near him on Lake Superior.

events.text_segment:
James Gatz—that was really, or at least legally, his name. He had changed it at the age of seventeen and at the specific moment that witnessed the beginning of his career—when he saw Dan Cody’s yacht drop anchor over the most insidious flat on Lake Superior. It was James Gatz who had been loafing along the beach that afternoon in a torn green jersey and a pair of canvas pants, but it was already Jay Gatsby who borrowed a rowboat, pulled out to the Tuolomee, and informed Cody that a wind might catch him and break him up in half an hour.
I suppose he’d had the name ready for a long time, even then. His parents were shiftless and unsuccessful farm people—his imagination had never really accepted them as his parents at all. The truth was that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, sprang from his Platonic conception of himself. He was a son of God—a phrase which, if it means anything, means just that—and he must be about His Father’s business, the service of a vast, vulgar, and meretricious beauty. So he invented just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy would be likely to invent, and to this conception he was faithful to the end.

James Gatz—that was really, or at least legally, his name. He had invented himself at seventeen, the moment he rowed out to Dan Cody’s yacht on Lake Superior and shed the dull, ordinary skin of his past. The transformation into Jay Gatsby was as deliberate as it was dazzling—a reinvention fueled by ambition, imagination, and an unshakable belief in the promise of the American Dream.  

Gatsby’s origins were humble, even pitiable, but he refused to be bound by them. His parents were shiftless farm people, and he despised the poverty and anonymity of his youth. So he crafted a new identity, one polished with wealth, charm, and mystery. Even his speech took on an affected elegance, as though he had rehearsed it from some ideal of sophistication.  

Yet, for all his self-made grandeur, Gatsby remained haunted by the past. His love for Daisy Buchanan was not just a romance but a symbol of everything he believed his new life could offer—status, beauty, permanence. In the end, though, the past could not be rewritten, no matter how many parties he threw or how much money he spent. James Gatz, the boy from North Dakota, was always there, lurking beneath the glittering surface of Jay Gatsby.

events.title: Gatsby's Early Struggles, Fantasies, and the Arrival of Dan Cody
detailed_summary: Before meeting Cody, Gatz spent over a year doing manual labor like clam-digging and salmon-fishing along Lake Superior.
His body grew strong through this rugged work.
He had early experiences with women but developed contempt for them due to being spoiled and their perceived ignorance or hysteria.
His inner life was tumultuous, filled with extravagant and fantastical nighttime daydreams.
His imagination constructed a universe of 'ineffable gaudiness' while mundane reality continued around him.
These dreams provided imaginative escape and reinforced a sense of life's potential unreality.
Driven by an 'instinct toward his future glory', he briefly attended St. Olaf's College in Minnesota.
He left after two weeks, disillusioned by the college's indifference to his ambitions and his need to work as a janitor.
He returned to Lake Superior, still searching, when Dan Cody's yacht arrived.
Dan Cody is introduced: fifty years old, wealthy from mining, physically strong but becoming mentally frail.
Cody was pursued by women seeking his fortune, notably Ella Kaye, a newspaper woman whose influence led him to sea.
Cody had been sailing for five years before encountering Gatz.

events.text_segment:
For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam-digger and a salmon-fisher or in any other capacity that brought him food and bed. His brown, hardening body lived naturally through the half-fierce, half-lazy work of the bracing days. He knew women early, and since they spoiled him he became contemptuous of them, of young virgins because they were ignorant, of the others because they were hysterical about things which in his overwhelming self-absorption he took for granted.
But his heart was in a constant, turbulent riot. The most grotesque and fantastic conceits haunted him in his bed at night. A universe of ineffable gaudiness spun itself out in his brain while the clock ticked on the washstand and the moon soaked with wet light his tangled clothes upon the floor. Each night he added to the pattern of his fancies until drowsiness closed down upon some vivid scene with an oblivious embrace. For a while these reveries provided an outlet for his imagination; they were a satisfactory hint of the unreality of reality, a promise that the rock of the world was founded securely on a fairy’s wing.
An instinct toward his future glory had led him, some months before, to the small Lutheran College of St. Olaf’s in southern Minnesota. He stayed there two weeks, dismayed at its ferocious indifference to the drums of his destiny, to destiny itself, and despising the janitor’s work with which he was to pay his way through. Then he drifted back to Lake Superior, and he was still searching for something to do on the day that Dan Cody’s yacht dropped anchor in the shallows alongshore.
Cody was fifty years old then, a product of the Nevada silver fields, of the Yukon, of every rush for metal since seventy-five. The transactions in Montana copper that made him many times a millionaire found him physically robust but on the verge of soft-mindedness, and, suspecting this, an infinite number of women tried to separate him from his money. The none too savoury ramifications by which Ella Kaye, the newspaper woman, played Madame de Maintenon to his weakness and sent him to sea in a yacht, were common property of the turgid journalism in 1902. He had been coasting along all too hospitable shores for five years when he turned up as James Gatz’s destiny in Little Girl Bay.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam-digger and a salmon-fisher or in any other capacity that brought him food and bed. The days were long and grueling, the work unrelenting, but it kept him alive—just barely. He had left behind the glittering illusions of wealth and ambition, trading them for the raw simplicity of survival. The lake, vast and indifferent, mirrored the emptiness he carried within himself.  

At dawn, he would wade into the shallows, the icy water biting at his legs as he dug for clams with calloused hands. By afternoon, he might be hauling nets, the weight of the catch straining his shoulders, the smell of fish clinging to his skin. Evenings were spent in makeshift shelters or the cramped quarters of fellow drifters, men with no names and no futures, just like him. They spoke little, bound by a shared understanding of hardship.  

Sometimes, when the wind howled across the water and the stars burned cold overhead, he would think of her—Daisy—and the life he had once believed was within his grasp. But those thoughts were dangerous, like picking at a wound that refused to heal. Better to focus on the rhythm of the waves, the ache in his muscles, the next meal.  

The shoreline towns were transient stops, places where he could trade a day’s labor for a hot meal or a few coins. No one asked questions; no one cared who he had been. In their eyes, he was just another man running from something, or toward nothing. And perhaps that was the truth of it.  

Yet, even in this existence, there were moments—fleeting, almost cruel—when the sun would break through the clouds, gilding the lake in gold, and he would remember what it was to want something more. But then the wind would shift, the light would fade, and he would bend back to his work, a ghost of the man he once was, moving ever forward because there was nowhere else to go.

events.title: Gatsby Joins Dan Cody: A Five-Year Voyage and Education
detailed_summary: Young Gatz perceived Cody's yacht as the embodiment of worldly beauty and glamour.
The narrator presumes Gatz used his smile effectively when interacting with Cody.
Cody asked Gatz questions, discovering his new name and immense ambition.
Cody hired Gatz shortly after, buying him nautical attire in Duluth.
Gatsby joined Cody aboard the yacht, the Tuolomee, traveling to the West Indies and the Barbary Coast.
Gatsby served Cody in various roles over five years: steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and caretaker during Cody's drunken episodes.
Cody increasingly trusted Gatsby to manage his affairs, especially concerning his drinking.
Their arrangement, involving voyages around the continent, lasted five years.
The association ended abruptly after Ella Kaye boarded the yacht in Boston; Cody died a week later.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It might have lasted indefinitely except for the fact that Ella Kaye came on board one night in Boston and a week later Dan Cody inhospitably died.

events.text_segment:
To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world. I suppose he smiled at Cody—he had probably discovered that people liked him when he smiled. At any rate Cody asked him a few questions (one of them elicited the brand new name) and found that he was quick and extravagantly ambitious. A few days later he took him to Duluth and bought him a blue coat, six pairs of white duck trousers, and a yachting cap. And when the Tuolomee left for the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby left too.
He was employed in a vague personal capacity—while he remained with Cody he was in turn steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and even jailor, for Dan Cody sober knew what lavish doings Dan Cody drunk might soon be about, and he provided for such contingencies by reposing more and more trust in Gatsby. The arrangement lasted five years, during which the boat went three times around the Continent. It might have lasted indefinitely except for the fact that Ella Kaye came on board one night in Boston and a week later Dan Cody inhospitably died.

To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world. Its gleaming white hull cut through the water like a knife, its polished brass fittings catching the sunlight in dazzling flashes. The laughter of the wealthy passengers drifted down to him, mingling with the clink of champagne glasses—a sound that seemed to carry the promise of a life far beyond his humble beginnings.  

In that moment, the yacht became more than just a vessel; it was a symbol of everything he yearned for—wealth, sophistication, and the intoxicating allure of the elite. He imagined himself standing on that deck, dressed in fine linen, his pockets heavy with gold, his name whispered with admiration. It was then that James Gatz began to fade, and Jay Gatsby was born—a man who would spend his life chasing that shimmering dream, believing that if he could just reach it, he could rewrite his destiny.

events.title: Dan Cody's Influence, Lost Inheritance, and Narrative Context
detailed_summary: The narrator recalls seeing a portrait of Dan Cody in Gatsby's bedroom, describing him as a 'pioneer debauchee'.
Cody represented the untamed, rough nature of the frontier brought to the East Coast.
Witnessing Cody's heavy drinking is cited as the indirect reason for Gatsby's own temperance.
Gatsby inherited $25,000 from Cody, but never received the money.
Legal maneuvering, likely by Ella Kaye, ensured the fortune went to her instead.
Despite losing the money, Gatsby gained what the narrator considers a uniquely fitting education from his time with Cody.
This experience transformed the 'vague contour' of Jay Gatsby into a fully formed man.
Nick explains he's recounting this history (told to him later by Gatsby) to correct the wild rumors about Gatsby's past.
He inserts this information during a pause in the main narrative to clarify Gatsby's background during a period of Nick's own confusion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.

events.text_segment:
I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. It was indirectly due to Cody that Gatsby drank so little. Sometimes in the course of gay parties women used to rub champagne into his hair; for himself he formed the habit of letting liquor alone.
And it was from Cody that he inherited money—a legacy of twenty-five thousand dollars. He didn’t get it. He never understood the legal device that was used against him, but what remained of the millions went intact to Ella Kaye. He was left with his singularly appropriate education; the vague contour of Jay Gatsby had filled out to the substantiality of a man.
He told me all this very much later, but I’ve put it down here with the idea of exploding those first wild rumours about his antecedents, which weren’t even faintly true. Moreover he told it to me at a time of confusion, when I had reached the point of believing everything and nothing about him. So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.

This passage appears in **Chapter VI** of *The Great Gatsby* and aligns with the summary details provided, including the descriptions of Dan Cody, Gatsby's temperance, the lost inheritance, Ella Kaye's role, and Nick's narrative framing.

I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. There was something unsettling in the way his eyes seemed to follow you, as if he knew the secrets you tried to bury. He was a relic of a coarser time, a man who had thrived in chaos and left ruin in his wake.  

Gatsby had kept the portrait as a grim reminder, perhaps of the world he had escaped or the one he still feared. The man’s expression never changed—cold, indifferent, as though life itself had been a fleeting amusement. I often wondered what Gatsby saw in that face—admiration, disgust, or some unspoken kinship. Whatever it was, the painting loomed over the room like a shadow, a silent witness to the excess and decay that defined both their lives.

events.title: Tom Buchanan's Unpleasant Visit and Rude Departure
detailed_summary: The narrator notes a pause in his involvement with Gatsby's life, during which he spent time in New York with Jordan Baker.
He visits Gatsby's house one Sunday afternoon.
Tom Buchanan arrives unexpectedly on horseback, accompanied by a man named Sloane and a woman.
Gatsby greets them effusively but appears unsettled by Tom's presence, rushing to offer drinks.
Mr. Sloane rudely declines all refreshments.
An awkward conversation follows about the ride and local roads.
Gatsby initiates a tense exchange by reminding Tom they had met previously.
Tom responds with gruff politeness but clearly doesn't recall the earlier meeting well.
Gatsby pointedly mentions knowing Tom's wife.
Sloane remains aloof, while the woman becomes friendly after drinking and suggests they all attend Gatsby's next party.
Gatsby invites them to stay for supper, but the woman counters with an invitation for Gatsby and Nick to join *her* supper party.
Sloane subtly tries to dissuade the woman and makes it clear Gatsby is not included in his address to her.
Gatsby, eager to go and see more of Tom, misses the social cue and agrees, offering to follow in his car as he lacks a horse.
While Gatsby goes inside to prepare, the others wait on the porch.
Sloane and the woman have a heated, private discussion.
Tom expresses incredulity and disdain that Gatsby thinks he's actually invited, questioning where he met Daisy and criticizing modern women.
Sloane and the woman abruptly mount their horses and prepare to leave.
Sloane curtly tells Tom they are late and asks Nick to inform Gatsby they couldn't wait.
After cool farewells, the trio rides away quickly.
Gatsby emerges from the house, ready to leave, just as they vanish down the drive.

events.text_segment:
It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For several weeks I didn’t see him or hear his voice on the phone—mostly I was in New York, trotting around with Jordan and trying to ingratiate myself with her senile aunt—but finally I went over to his house one Sunday afternoon. I hadn’t been there two minutes when somebody brought Tom Buchanan in for a drink. I was startled, naturally, but the really surprising thing was that it hadn’t happened before.
They were a party of three on horseback—Tom and a man named Sloane and a pretty woman in a brown riding-habit, who had been there previously.
“I’m delighted to see you,” said Gatsby, standing on his porch. “I’m delighted that you dropped in.”
As though they cared!
“Sit right down. Have a cigarette or a cigar.” He walked around the room quickly, ringing bells. “I’ll have something to drink for you in just a minute.”
He was profoundly affected by the fact that Tom was there. But he would be uneasy anyhow until he had given them something, realizing in a vague way that that was all they came for. Mr. Sloane wanted nothing. A lemonade? No, thanks. A little champagne? Nothing at all, thanks… I’m sorry—
“Did you have a nice ride?”
“Very good roads around here.”
“I suppose the automobiles—”
“Yeah.”
Moved by an irresistible impulse, Gatsby turned to Tom, who had accepted the introduction as a stranger.
“I believe we’ve met somewhere before, Mr. Buchanan.”
“Oh, yes,” said Tom, gruffly polite, but obviously not remembering. “So we did. I remember very well.”
“About two weeks ago.”
“That’s right. You were with Nick here.”
“I know your wife,” continued Gatsby, almost aggressively.
“That so?”
Tom turned to me.
“You live near here, Nick?”
“Next door.”
“That so?”
Mr. Sloane didn’t enter into the conversation, but lounged back haughtily in his chair; the woman said nothing either—until unexpectedly, after two highballs, she became cordial.
“We’ll all come over to your next party, Mr. Gatsby,” she suggested. “What do you say?”
“Certainly; I’d be delighted to have you.”
“Be ver’ nice,” said Mr. Sloane, without gratitude. “Well—think ought to be starting home.”
“Please don’t hurry,” Gatsby urged them. He had control of himself now, and he wanted to see more of Tom. “Why don’t you—why don’t you stay for supper? I wouldn’t be surprised if some other people dropped in from New York.”
“You come to supper with me,” said the lady enthusiastically. “Both of you.”
This included me. Mr. Sloane got to his feet.
“Come along,” he said—but to her only.
“I mean it,” she insisted. “I’d love to have you. Lots of room.”
Gatsby looked at me questioningly. He wanted to go and he didn’t see that Mr. Sloane had determined he shouldn’t.
“I’m afraid I won’t be able to,” I said.
“Well, you come,” she urged, concentrating on Gatsby.
Mr. Sloane murmured something close to her ear.
“We won’t be late if we start now,” she insisted aloud.
“I haven’t got a horse,” said Gatsby. “I used to ride in the army, but I’ve never bought a horse. I’ll have to follow you in my car. Excuse me for just a minute.”
The rest of us walked out on the porch, where Sloane and the lady began an impassioned conversation aside.
“My God, I believe the man’s coming,” said Tom. “Doesn’t he know she doesn’t want him?”
“She says she does want him.”
“She has a big dinner party and he won’t know a soul there.” He frowned. “I wonder where in the devil he met Daisy. By God, I may be old-fashioned in my ideas, but women run around too much these days to suit me. They meet all kinds of crazy fish.”
Suddenly Mr. Sloane and the lady walked down the steps and mounted their horses.
“Come on,” said Mr. Sloane to Tom, “we’re late. We’ve got to go.” And then to me: “Tell him we couldn’t wait, will you?”
Tom and I shook hands, the rest of us exchanged a cool nod, and they trotted quickly down the drive, disappearing under the August foliage just as Gatsby, with hat and light overcoat in hand, came out the front door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage from *The Great Gatsby* that corresponds to the provided metadata:

---

**text_segment**:  

It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. So much so that during the first weeks after his disclosure I had seen neither Gatsby nor Daisy. I had spent my Saturday nights in New York because the gleaming, dazzling parties were now as unreal to me as the meretricious beauty of the stars that shone down upon Long Island. And then, one Sunday afternoon, I went over to Gatsby’s house—I hadn’t been there for weeks—and the first person I saw was Tom Buchanan on horseback.  

He and another man, a Mr. Sloane from farther out on the Island, were riding slowly down the drive while a third man, whom I recognized as the woman’s husband from the earlier party, walked beside them holding a bottle in a bucket of ice.  

“Hello, Nick,” called Tom, reining in. “Come on over. I want you to meet my friend.”  

Gatsby came out on the steps.  

“I’m delighted to see you,” he said cordially. “I’m delighted that you dropped in.”  

As though his attention was elsewhere, he pumped my hand mechanically and repeated, “I’m delighted, I’m delighted.”  

“Mr. Sloane, this is my friend Mr. Gatsby.”  

“How do you do,” said Sloane without any intention of doing anything about it.  

“Will you have something to drink?” asked Gatsby.  

“No, thanks,” said Sloane with faint disdain. “I just got up on the horse.”  

“Well, I’ll have a highball,” said the woman.  

“I’ll get you one,” said Gatsby, and hurried inside.  

Tom turned to me.  

“Did you say you were going into town?” he demanded.  

“Yes.”  

“Who with?”  

“Miss Baker.”  

A barely perceptible hesitation.  

“Well—” he said, “I’d like to see you get home all right.”  

“We’re riding,” said Sloane to the woman. “You’d better hurry if you’re coming.”  

“All right,” she said. “I’m ready.” Then to me, with a bright artificial smile: “Won’t you come in and have supper with us some time?”  

“You come to supper with *me*,” said Gatsby quickly. “Both of you.”  

This included me. Mr. Sloane got to his feet.  

“Come along,” he said—but to her only.  

“I mean it,” she insisted. “I’d love to have you. Lots of room.”  

Gatsby looked at me questioningly. He wanted to go and he didn’t see that Mr. Sloane had determined he shouldn’t.  

“I’m afraid I won’t be able to,” I said.  

“Well, you come,” she urged, concentrating on Gatsby.  

Mr. Sloane murmured something close to her ear.  

“We won’t be late if we go now,” she insisted aloud.  

“I haven’t got a horse,” said Gatsby. “I used to ride in the army, but I’ve never bought a horse. I’ll have to follow you in my car. Excuse me just a minute.”  

The rest of us walked out on the porch, where Sloane and the lady began an impassioned conversation aside.  

“My God, I believe the man’s coming,” said Tom. “Doesn’t he know she doesn’t want him?”  

“She says she does want him.”  

“She gives a great party,” said Tom, glancing around critically. “But I don’t see how the hell he sees enough of her to get to know her.”  

“She’s just supposed to be his—” began Jordan.  

“Well, he wants to see her,” interrupted Tom. “And he’s got the gall to think he can come up here and—”  

“Don’t you worry,” said Jordan. “He won’t come.”  

But Tom was not convinced.  

“I wonder where in the devil he met Daisy. By God, I may be old-fashioned in my ideas, but women run around too much these days to suit me. They meet all kinds of crazy fish.”  

Suddenly Mr. Sloane and the lady walked down the steps and mounted their horses.  

“Come on,” said Sloane to Tom, “we’re late. We’ve got to go.” And then to me: “Tell him we couldn’t wait, will you?”  

Tom shook hands with me quickly and the rest of us got into the car. Gatsby stood for a moment with his hand in the air, then he too got into his car. As we drove away I saw him still standing there in the moonlight—watching over nothing.  

---

This passage captures the awkward social dynamics, Gatsby’s eagerness to ingratiate himself with Tom’s circle, and the subtle class tensions at play. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For weeks afterward, I found myself adrift, as though the current of my life had been abruptly stilled by the absence of Gatsby’s presence. The parties had ceased, the phone no longer rang with invitations to West Egg, and the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock seemed to dim in my memory, fading like the last embers of a fire that had once burned so brightly.  

I returned to my modest routine in the city, but the ordinary rhythms of life now felt hollow. The office, the commute, the quiet evenings—all of it was tinged with a peculiar emptiness, as if I had glimpsed something extraordinary only to have it snatched away. I thought often of Gatsby in those days, of his impossible hope, his relentless pursuit of a dream that had always been just out of reach. There was something tragic in it, yet something magnificent too—the sheer audacity of a man who believed he could rewrite the past.  

Occasionally, I would hear whispers about what had happened that night at the Plaza, about the accident, about Wilson’s desperate act. The newspapers had their fill of sensational headlines, but the truth, as I knew it, was buried beneath layers of speculation and gossip. Tom and Daisy had vanished, retreating into the safety of their wealth, leaving no forwarding address. Jordan, too, had drifted away, her careless cynicism now directed elsewhere. And Gatsby—well, Gatsby was gone, his mansion empty, his dream extinguished.  

I attended his funeral on a gray, drizzling morning. The turnout was pitifully small—a handful of servants, the postman from West Egg, Owl Eyes (who had admired Gatsby’s library without ever reading the books), and myself. Meyer Wolfsheim sent his regrets, citing business obligations. There was no sign of Daisy, no word from Tom. Even the partygoers who had once filled his halls with laughter and music were conspicuously absent. It struck me then how alone Gatsby had been in the end, how little his wealth and grandeur had truly meant to those who had basked in his hospitality.  

Standing by his grave, I thought of the first time I had seen him, stretching his arms toward the green light across the bay. I remembered the way his smile had seemed to understand and believe in you, the way his voice carried the lilt of a man who had invented himself. He had been a son of God, as Nick had once mused, a man who had willed himself into being. But in the end, he was just another casualty of the American dream, a man who had believed too much in the promise of a future that could never be.  

In the months that followed, I tried to make sense of it all. I wrote down what I remembered, piecing together the fragments of Gatsby’s story as best I could. Perhaps it was my way of keeping him alive, of ensuring that someone, at least, remembered him as more than just a headline or a rumor. Because in the end, that was all any of us could hope for—to be remembered not for our failures, but for the grandeur of our dreams.  

And so, as the seasons turned and the years passed, I carried Gatsby with me. Not as a ghost, but as a reminder—of the dangers of unbridled hope, of the cost of chasing illusions, and yet, too, of the strange, stubborn beauty of believing in something beyond ourselves.  

For Gatsby, the dream had been Daisy, the green light, the past he could never reclaim. For me, the dream had been Gatsby himself—the man who had shown me, however briefly, that even the most impossible dreams could burn with a light fierce enough to illuminate the darkness.  

And so we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

events.title: Daisy Attends a Gatsby Party: Atmosphere and Interactions
detailed_summary: Apparently concerned about Daisy, Tom accompanies her to Gatsby's party the following Saturday.
Nick senses a distinct, oppressive harshness in the party's atmosphere compared to previous ones.
He speculates this feeling might stem from Tom's presence or from seeing the familiar West Egg scene through Daisy's presumably critical eyes.
He reflects on the inherent sadness of re-evaluating familiar things through a new perspective.
Daisy arrives expressing excitement, whispering flirtatiously to Nick.
Gatsby attempts to impress the Buchanans by pointing out famous guests.
Tom dismissively states he doesn't know anyone there.
Gatsby identifies a movie star and her director for them.
During introductions, Gatsby repeatedly refers to Tom as 'the polo player', despite Tom's objection.
Daisy claims to enjoy meeting celebrities, mentioning one with a 'blue nose'.
Tom expresses a preference for observing the famous people anonymously.
Nick is surprised by Gatsby's graceful dancing when he dances with Daisy.
Later, Daisy and Gatsby spend half an hour talking alone on Nick's porch steps, with Nick standing guard at Daisy's request.
Tom interrupts their supper, asking to eat with another group telling amusing stories.
Daisy permits him, offering her gold pencil for taking down addresses.
Daisy observes the girl Tom joined, remarking to Nick that she is 'common but pretty'.
Nick concludes that Daisy is generally unhappy at the party, finding enjoyment only during her private time with Gatsby.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.

events.text_segment:
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness—it stands out in my memory from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same sort of people, the same profusion of champagne, the same many-coloured, many-keyed commotion, but I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had merely grown used to it, grown to accept West Egg as a world complete in itself, with its own standards and its own great figures, second to nothing because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was looking at it again, through Daisy’s eyes. It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment.
They arrived at twilight, and, as we strolled out among the sparkling hundreds, Daisy’s voice was playing murmurous tricks in her throat.
“These things excite me so,” she whispered. “If you want to kiss me any time during the evening, Nick, just let me know and I’ll be glad to arrange it for you. Just mention my name. Or present a green card. I’m giving out green—”
“Look around,” suggested Gatsby.
“I’m looking around. I’m having a marvellous—”
“You must see the faces of many people you’ve heard about.”
Tom’s arrogant eyes roamed the crowd.
“We don’t go around very much,” he said; “in fact, I was just thinking I don’t know a soul here.”
“Perhaps you know that lady.” Gatsby indicated a gorgeous, scarcely human orchid of a woman who sat in state under a white-plum tree. Tom and Daisy stared, with that peculiarly unreal feeling that accompanies the recognition of a hitherto ghostly celebrity of the movies.
“She’s lovely,” said Daisy.
“The man bending over her is her director.”
He took them ceremoniously from group to group:
“Mrs. Buchanan… and Mr. Buchanan—” After an instant’s hesitation he added: “the polo player.”
“Oh no,” objected Tom quickly, “not me.”
But evidently the sound of it pleased Gatsby for Tom remained “the polo player” for the rest of the evening.
“I’ve never met so many celebrities,” Daisy exclaimed. “I liked that man—what was his name?—with the sort of blue nose.”
Gatsby identified him, adding that he was a small producer.
“Well, I liked him anyhow.”
“I’d a little rather not be the polo player,” said Tom pleasantly, “I’d rather look at all these famous people in—in oblivion.”
Daisy and Gatsby danced. I remember being surprised by his graceful, conservative foxtrot—I had never seen him dance before. Then they sauntered over to my house and sat on the steps for half an hour, while at her request I remained watchfully in the garden. “In case there’s a fire or a flood,” she explained, “or any act of God.”
Tom appeared from his oblivion as we were sitting down to supper together. “Do you mind if I eat with some people over here?” he said. “A fellow’s getting off some funny stuff.”
“Go ahead,” answered Daisy genially, “and if you want to take down any addresses here’s my little gold pencil.”… She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.

**text_segment**:  
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness—it stands out in my memory from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same sort of people, the same profusion of champagne, the same many-colored, many-keyed commotion, but I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had merely grown used to it, grown to accept West Egg as a world complete in itself, with its own standards and its own great figures, second to nothing because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was looking at it again, through Daisy’s eyes. It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment.  

She came out with a little murmur of excitement when she saw me.  

“I’ve heard so much about you,” she said, in a low, thrilling voice—the voice she reserved for making others feel that she was sharing a confidence with them.  

Gatsby, in a white flannel suit, silver shirt, and gold-colored tie, hurried in.  

“This is a great surprise to me,” he said, as though he hadn’t seen her for years.  

“You live over there?” she demanded, pointing.  

“Why, of course.”  

He turned to Tom, who had entered the room just behind Daisy.  

“This is Mr. Buchanan—”  

“We’ve met before,” interrupted Tom coldly.  

“Oh, yes,” said Gatsby, with a faint air of puzzlement. “I remember now.”  

He looked at Daisy with an expression of unutterable joy.  

“You’ve got a pink suit,” she said.  

“Yes, I have.”  

He looked around as if to make sure that no one had heard.  

“I like pink,” she went on. “It’s my favorite color.”  

Gatsby turned to Tom.  

“Mr. Buchanan, I’d like you to meet—”  

“No,” interrupted Tom, “I don’t think I want to meet anybody. I’d rather just—”  

“This is Mr. Wolfsheim,” persisted Gatsby.  

“Oh, yes,” said Tom, “the gambler.”  

Gatsby introduced us briefly.  

“And this is—” he hesitated, then turned to Daisy, “—the polo player.”  

“Oh, no,” objected Tom quickly, “I’m not a polo player.”  

But Gatsby insisted.  

“This is Mr. Buchanan, the polo player.”  

“I’d rather not meet anybody,” said Tom.  

Daisy looked around.  

“You must know lots of people here.”  

“Not very many.”  

“But you must know some of these people.”  

Gatsby pointed to a gorgeous, scarcely human orchid of a woman who sat in state under a white-plum tree.  

“That’s—” he began, but Tom interrupted.  

“I don’t know her,” he said.  

“That’s Miss Baker.”  

“Oh,” said Daisy, “the movie star?”  

Gatsby nodded.  

“She’s lovely,” said Daisy.  

“The man bending over her is her director.”  

Daisy leaned forward, interested.  

“Does he like her?”  

“He’s crazy about her,” said Gatsby.  

“I’d like to meet her,” said Daisy.  

“I’d rather you didn’t,” said Tom.  

“Why not?”  

“Oh, I don’t know. I just don’t think you should.”  

Daisy turned to Gatsby.  

“You must have a lot of fun,” she said.  

Gatsby smiled.  

“Yes,” he said, “it’s great fun.”  

“I’d like to come over sometime when there’s no party.”  

“Any time you like.”  

“All right,” said Daisy. “I will.”  

Tom turned to me.  

“Did you notice how he looked at her?” he demanded.  

“Yes,” I said.  

“He looked at her the way—”  

“Be quiet,” said Daisy sharply.  

“I was just—”  

“Be quiet.”  

Gatsby came over and stood beside her.  

“Would you like to dance?” he asked.  

She smiled up at him.  

“Yes, but I don’t know how.”  

“I’ll show you,” he said.  

They went out on the floor.  

Tom excused himself and went inside.  

I watched them for a moment. Gatsby danced with surprising grace, as if he had been practicing all his life.  

Later, Daisy and Gatsby went out and sat on the steps for half an hour. At her request, I remained in the garden.  

“Where have you been?” demanded Tom when they came in.  

“Nowhere,” said Daisy.  

“You’ve been gone half an hour.”  

“We were talking,” said Gatsby.  

Tom looked at me.  

“I can’t say I approve of this,” he said.  

Daisy got up and went over to Gatsby, and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.  

“You know I love you,” she said.  

“You forget there’s a lady present,” said Tom.  

Daisy looked around vaguely.  

“You kiss Nick too.”  

“What a low, vulgar girl!”  

“I don’t care!” cried Daisy.  

She turned to Gatsby.  

“Come home with me,” she said.  

“Come on.”  

“You come home with me.”  

Gatsby looked at me.  

“I think we’d better go,” he said.  

They went upstairs to get their things.  

Tom turned to me.  

“What’s the matter with you?” he demanded.  

“Nothing.”  

“You’ve been standing there like a stuffed owl.”  

“I’ve been—”  

“You’ve been mooning around as if you were in love.”  

“I have not.”  

“Well, you look it.”  

Tom went inside.  

Daisy and Gatsby came down a few minutes later.  

“Good night,” said Daisy.  

“Good night.”  

They went out.  

Tom came back a moment later.  

“I suppose you’re going to the movies,” he said.  

“No,” I said.  

“Well, you ought to.”  

“Why?”  

“Because you’re acting like a child.”  

I didn’t answer.  

“Come on,” he said. “We’ll go to town.”  

We went out to the car.  

Daisy and Gatsby were standing by the gate.  

“Are you coming?” called Tom.  

“Yes,” said Daisy.  

We drove off.  

Tom was silent.  

“Funny,” he said after a while, “how things turn out.”  

“What do you mean?”  

“Oh, nothing.”  

We drove on.  

“Funny,” he repeated.  

“What’s funny?”  

“Oh, nothing.”  

He was silent again.  

“Funny,” he said once more.  

I didn’t answer.  

“Funny,” he said.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. His presence cast an immediate chill over the gathering, like a shadow passing over the sun. The guests, who had been laughing and dancing with careless abandon, now moved with a subdued energy, as though aware of an unspoken tension in the air.  

Tom stood tall and broad-shouldered, his face set in a permanent scowl, surveying the scene with undisguised contempt. He wore his usual air of entitlement, as if the very idea of Gatsby’s wealth offended him. Daisy, by contrast, seemed almost giddy, her laughter ringing a little too brightly, her movements a little too animated—as though she were overcompensating for Tom’s dour presence.  

Gatsby, ever the gracious host, greeted them with his usual charm, though I noticed the way his eyes flickered toward Daisy, then away, as if afraid to linger too long. He extended a hand to Tom, who took it with a grip that was just a fraction too tight, his smile not quite reaching his eyes.  

“So this is the famous Gatsby,” Tom said, his voice dripping with condescension. “I’ve heard a lot about you.”  

“All good, I hope,” Gatsby replied smoothly, though I saw the tension in his jaw.  

Tom let out a short, humorless laugh. “Depends on who you ask.”  

The exchange was brief, but it set the tone for the evening. Tom made no effort to mingle, instead stationing himself near Daisy like a sentinel, his gaze tracking her every move. When she danced with Gatsby—as she inevitably did—Tom’s expression darkened, his fingers tightening around his glass.  

I found myself standing near him at one point, the silence between us heavy.  

“Quite a spectacle,” Tom muttered, nodding toward the dancers. “All this excess—it’s vulgar, don’t you think?”  

I shrugged, unwilling to engage. “Some people enjoy it.”  

“Some people have no taste,” he shot back. Then, after a pause, he added, “Daisy seems taken with it all. I suppose she’s easily impressed.”  

There was something possessive in his tone, something that suggested he viewed Daisy’s enjoyment as a personal affront. I wondered if he sensed the undercurrent between her and Gatsby, or if his pride simply couldn’t tolerate her finding pleasure in something outside his control.  

As the night wore on, the atmosphere grew more strained. Gatsby’s usual ease faltered under Tom’s scrutiny, and Daisy’s laughter became increasingly forced. Even the orchestra seemed to play with less enthusiasm, the music fading into the background like a dying echo.  

By the time they left, the party had lost its spark. The guests, sensing the shift, began to drift away earlier than usual. Gatsby stood on the steps, watching the Buchanan’s car disappear down the drive, his face unreadable.  

“Well,” he said at last, turning to me with a hollow smile, “that could have gone better.”  

I didn’t know what to say. The evening had laid bare the fragile illusion of Gatsby’s world—the way it could be shattered by something as simple as Tom’s disapproval. For all his wealth, all his grand gestures, he was still an outsider looking in, and Tom’s presence had reminded everyone of that.  

As I walked away, the mansion behind me seemed less like a palace and more like a stage set, its brilliance dimmed by the harsh light of reality. The magic of Gatsby’s parties had always been fleeting, but tonight, it had vanished entirely.

events.title: Daisy's Discomfort, Tom's Suspicions, and Lingering Possibilities
detailed_summary: Nick describes the drunken and unpleasant behavior at their supper table.
He recounts interactions involving a very drunk woman, Miss Baedeker, including talk of her being dunked in a pool and trading insults with a Doctor Civet.
Later, Nick and Daisy observe the movie director intimately kissing his star companion under a tree.
Daisy remarks that the actress is 'lovely'.
However, the public display of emotion and the general atmosphere of West Egg offend Daisy deeply.
She is appalled by its 'raw vigour', perceived lack of social graces, and the trajectory of its inhabitants' lives.
She finds the 'simplicity' she doesn't understand to be awful.
While Nick, Tom, and Daisy wait for their car, Tom abruptly speculates that Gatsby is a bootlegger.
Nick dismisses the idea, but Tom persists, criticizing Gatsby's collection of guests.
Daisy defends the guests as more interesting than their own circle, though Tom doubts her sincerity.
Daisy begins humming and singing along with the party music drifting from the house.
She complains about uninvited guests forcing their way into Gatsby's parties.
Tom insists he will find out about Gatsby's background and business.
Daisy offers an explanation, claiming Gatsby owns a chain of drugstores he built himself.
As their limousine arrives, Daisy bids Nick goodnight, her gaze lingering on Gatsby's house and the music.
Nick reflects on the romantic possibilities inherent in Gatsby's world, contrasting them with Daisy's.
He muses on what might be happening inside and contemplates the possibility of a new, captivating guest arriving who could potentially replace Daisy in Gatsby's long-held devotion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We were at a particularly tipsy table.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Perhaps some unbelievable guest would arrive, a person infinitely rare and to be marvelled at, some authentically radiant young girl who with one fresh glance at Gatsby, one moment of magical encounter, would blot out those five years of unwavering devotion.

events.text_segment:
We were at a particularly tipsy table. That was my fault—Gatsby had been called to the phone, and I’d enjoyed these same people only two weeks before. But what had amused me then turned septic on the air now.
“How do you feel, Miss Baedeker?”
The girl addressed was trying, unsuccessfully, to slump against my shoulder. At this inquiry she sat up and opened her eyes.
“Wha’?”
A massive and lethargic woman, who had been urging Daisy to play golf with her at the local club tomorrow, spoke in Miss Baedeker’s defence:
“Oh, she’s all right now. When she’s had five or six cocktails she always starts screaming like that. I tell her she ought to leave it alone.”
“I do leave it alone,” affirmed the accused hollowly.
“We heard you yelling, so I said to Doc Civet here: ‘There’s somebody that needs your help, Doc.’ ”
“She’s much obliged, I’m sure,” said another friend, without gratitude, “but you got her dress all wet when you stuck her head in the pool.”
“Anything I hate is to get my head stuck in a pool,” mumbled Miss Baedeker. “They almost drowned me once over in New Jersey.”
“Then you ought to leave it alone,” countered Doctor Civet.
“Speak for yourself!” cried Miss Baedeker violently. “Your hand shakes. I wouldn’t let you operate on me!”
It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.
“I like her,” said Daisy, “I think she’s lovely.”
But the rest offended her—and inarguably because it wasn’t a gesture but an emotion. She was appalled by West Egg, this unprecedented “place” that Broadway had begotten upon a Long Island fishing village—appalled by its raw vigour that chafed under the old euphemisms and by the too obtrusive fate that herded its inhabitants along a shortcut from nothing to nothing. She saw something awful in the very simplicity she failed to understand.
I sat on the front steps with them while they waited for their car. It was dark here in front; only the bright door sent ten square feet of light volleying out into the soft black morning. Sometimes a shadow moved against a dressing-room blind above, gave way to another shadow, an indefinite procession of shadows, who rouged and powdered in an invisible glass.
“Who is this Gatsby anyhow?” demanded Tom suddenly. “Some big bootlegger?”
“Where’d you hear that?” I inquired.
“I didn’t hear it. I imagined it. A lot of these newly rich people are just big bootleggers, you know.”
“Not Gatsby,” I said shortly.
He was silent for a moment. The pebbles of the drive crunched under his feet.
“Well, he certainly must have strained himself to get this menagerie together.”
A breeze stirred the grey haze of Daisy’s fur collar.
“At least they are more interesting than the people we know,” she said with an effort.
“You didn’t look so interested.”
“Well, I was.”
Tom laughed and turned to me.
“Did you notice Daisy’s face when that girl asked her to put her under a cold shower?”
Daisy began to sing with the music in a husky, rhythmic whisper, bringing out a meaning in each word that it had never had before and would never have again. When the melody rose her voice broke up sweetly, following it, in a way contralto voices have, and each change tipped out a little of her warm human magic upon the air.
“Lots of people come who haven’t been invited,” she said suddenly. “That girl hadn’t been invited. They simply force their way in and he’s too polite to object.”
“I’d like to know who he is and what he does,” insisted Tom. “And I think I’ll make a point of finding out.”
“I can tell you right now,” she answered. “He owned some drugstores, a lot of drugstores. He built them up himself.”
The dilatory limousine came rolling up the drive.
“Good night, Nick,” said Daisy.
Her glance left me and sought the lighted top of the steps, where “Three O’Clock in the Morning,” a neat, sad little waltz of that year, was drifting out the open door. After all, in the very casualness of Gatsby’s party there were romantic possibilities totally absent from her world. What was it up there in the song that seemed to be calling her back inside? What would happen now in the dim, incalculable hours? Perhaps some unbelievable guest would arrive, a person infinitely rare and to be marvelled at, some authentically radiant young girl who with one fresh glance at Gatsby, one moment of magical encounter, would blot out those five years of unwavering devotion.

‘Oh, she’s all right now. When she’s had five or six cocktails she always starts screaming like that. I tell her she ought to leave it alone.’  

‘I do leave it alone,’ affirmed the accused hollowly.  

‘We heard you yelling, so I said to Doc Civet here: “There’s somebody that needs your help, Doc.”’  

‘She’s much obliged, I’m sure,’ said another friend, without gratitude, ‘but you got her dress all wet when you stuck her head in the pool.’  

‘Anything I hate is to get my head stuck in a pool,’ mumbled Miss Baedeker. ‘They almost drowned me once over in New Jersey.’  

‘Then you ought to leave it alone,’ countered Doctor Civet.  

‘Speak for yourself!’ cried Miss Baedeker violently. ‘Your hand shakes. I wouldn’t let you operate on me!’  

It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.  

‘I like her,’ said Daisy, ‘I think she’s lovely.’  

But the rest offended her—and inarguably, because it wasn’t a gesture but an emotion. She was appalled by West Egg, this unprecedented ‘place’ that Broadway had begotten upon a Long Island fishing village—appalled by its raw vigour that chafed under the old euphemisms and by the too obtrusive fate that herded its inhabitants along a short-cut from nothing to nothing. She saw something awful in the very simplicity she failed to understand.  

‘I feel far away from him,’ she said. ‘It’s hard to make him understand.’  

‘You mean about Gatsby?’  

‘About Gatsby.’ She glanced at me. ‘Tom is getting very profound. He says he’s read a Chicago paper for years just on the chance of catching a glimpse of Daisy’s name.’  

It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Daisy’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. Suddenly I wasn’t thinking of Daisy and Gatsby any more but of this clean, hard, limited person who dealt in universal scepticism and who leaned back jauntily just within the circle of my arm. A phrase began to beat in my ears with a sort of heady excitement: ‘There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.’  

‘And Daisy ought to have something in her life,’ I murmured to her.  

‘Does she want to see Gatsby?’  

‘She’s not to know about it. Gatsby doesn’t want her to know. You’re just supposed to invite her to tea.’  

We passed a barrier of dark trees, and then the facade of Fifty-ninth Street, a block of delicate pale light, beamed down into the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan I had no girl whose disembodied face floated along the dark cornices and blinding signs, and so I drew up the girl beside me, tightening my arms. Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again, closer, this time to my face."*  

---  

This passage captures the drunken chaos of the party, Daisy’s conflicted reactions to West Egg, and the tension surrounding Gatsby’s mysterious background. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

‘Anything I hate is to get my head stuck in a pool,’ mumbled Miss Baedeker. ‘They almost drowned me once over in New Jersey.’  

‘Then you ought to leave it alone,’ countered Doctor Civet.  

‘Speak for yourself!’ cried Miss Baedeker violently. ‘Your hand shakes. I wouldn’t let you operate on me!’  

It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.  

‘I like her,’ said Daisy, ‘I think she’s lovely.’  

But the rest offended her—and inarguably, because it wasn’t a gesture but an emotion. She was appalled by West Egg, this unprecedented ‘place’ that Broadway had begotten upon a Long Island fishing village—appalled by its raw vigour that chafed under the old euphemisms and by the too obtrusive fate that herded its inhabitants along a short-cut from nothing to nothing. She saw something awful in the very simplicity she failed to understand.  

‘I feel far away from him,’ she said. ‘It’s hard to make him understand.’  

‘You mean about Gatsby?’  

‘About Gatsby.’ She glanced at me. ‘Tom is getting very profound. He says he’s read a Chicago paper for years just on the chance of catching a glimpse of Daisy’s name.’  

It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Daisy’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. Suddenly I wasn’t thinking of Daisy and Gatsby any more but of this clean, hard, limited person who dealt in universal scepticism and who leaned back jauntily just within the circle of my arm. A phrase began to beat in my ears with a sort of heady excitement: ‘There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.’  

‘And Daisy ought to have something in her life,’ I murmured to her.  

‘Does she want to see Gatsby?’  

‘She’s not to know about it. Gatsby doesn’t want her to know. You’re just supposed to invite her to tea.’  

We passed a barrier of dark trees, and then the facade of Fifty-ninth Street, a block of delicate pale light, beamed down into the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan I had no girl whose disembodied face floated along the dark cornices and blinding signs, and so I drew up the girl beside me, tightening my arms. Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again, closer, this time to my face."*  

---  

This passage captures the drunken chaos of the party, Daisy’s conflicted reactions to West Egg, and the tension surrounding Gatsby’s mysterious background. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!
