*"We were at a particularly tipsy table. That was my fault—Gatsby had been called to the phone, and I’d enjoyed these same people only two weeks before. But what had amused me then turned septic on the air now.  

‘How do you feel, Miss Baedeker?’  

The girl addressed was trying, unsuccessfully, to slump against my shoulder. At this inquiry she sat up and opened her eyes.  

‘Wha’?’  

A massive and lethargic woman, who had been urging Daisy to play golf with her at the local club tomorrow, spoke in Miss Baedeker’s defence:  

‘Oh, she’s all right now. When she’s had five or six cocktails she always starts screaming like that. I tell her she ought to leave it alone.’  

‘I do leave it alone,’ affirmed the accused hollowly.  

‘We heard you yelling, so I said to Doc Civet here: “There’s somebody that needs your help, Doc.”’  

‘She’s much obliged, I’m sure,’ said another friend, without gratitude, ‘but you got her dress all wet when you stuck her head in the pool.’  

‘Anything I hate is to get my head stuck in a pool,’ mumbled Miss Baedeker. ‘They almost drowned me once over in New Jersey.’  

‘Then you ought to leave it alone,’ countered Doctor Civet.  

‘Speak for yourself!’ cried Miss Baedeker violently. ‘Your hand shakes. I wouldn’t let you operate on me!’  

It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.  

‘I like her,’ said Daisy, ‘I think she’s lovely.’  

But the rest offended her—and inarguably, because it wasn’t a gesture but an emotion. She was appalled by West Egg, this unprecedented ‘place’ that Broadway had begotten upon a Long Island fishing village—appalled by its raw vigour that chafed under the old euphemisms and by the too obtrusive fate that herded its inhabitants along a short-cut from nothing to nothing. She saw something awful in the very simplicity she failed to understand.  

At this point Jordan and I tried to go, but Tom and Gatsby insisted with competitive firmness that we remain—as though neither of them had anything to conceal and it would be a privilege to partake vicariously of their emotions.  

‘Sit down, Daisy,’ Tom’s voice groped unsuccessfully for the paternal note. ‘What’s been going on? I want to hear all about it.’  

‘I told you what’s been going on,’ said Gatsby. ‘Going on for five years—and you didn’t know.’  

Tom turned to me sharply.  

‘Did you say Nick was going on?’  

Before I could reply Daisy broke out:  

‘Oh, that’s all over,’ she said helplessly. ‘It doesn’t matter any more. Just tell him the truth—that you never loved him—and it’s all wiped out forever.’  

She looked at him blindly.  

‘Why—how could I love him—possibly?’  

‘You never loved him.’  

She hesitated. Her eyes fell on Jordan and me with a sort of appeal, as though she realized at last what she was doing—and as though she had never, all along, intended doing anything at all. But it was done now. It was too late.  

‘I never loved him,’ she said, with perceptible reluctance.  

‘Not at Kapiolani?’ demanded Tom suddenly.  

‘No.’  

From the ballroom beneath, muffled and suffocating chords were drifting up on hot waves of air.  

‘Not that day I carried you down from the Punch Bowl to keep your shoes dry?’ There was a husky tenderness in his tone. ‘…Daisy?’  

‘Please don’t.’ Her voice was cold, but the rancour was gone from it. She looked at Gatsby. ‘There, Jay,’ she said—but her hand as she tried to light a cigarette was trembling. Suddenly she threw the cigarette and the burning match on the carpet.  

‘Oh, you want too much!’ she cried to Gatsby. ‘I love you now—isn’t that enough? I can’t help what’s past.’ She began to sob helplessly. ‘I did love him once—but I loved you too.’  

Gatsby’s eyes opened and closed.  

‘You loved me too?’ he repeated.  

‘Even that’s a lie,’ said Tom savagely. ‘She didn’t know you were alive. Why—there’re things between Daisy and me that you’ll never know, things that neither of us can ever forget.’  

The words seemed to bite physically into Gatsby.  

‘I want to speak to Daisy alone,’ he insisted. ‘She’s all excited now—’  

‘Even alone I can’t say I never loved Tom,’ she admitted in a pitiful voice. ‘It wouldn’t be true.’  

‘Of course it wouldn’t,’ agreed Tom.  

She turned to her husband.  

‘As if it mattered to you,’ she said.  

‘Of course it matters. I’m going to take better care of you from now on.’  

‘You don’t understand,’ said Gatsby, with a touch of panic. ‘You’re not going to take care of her any more.’  

‘I’m not?’ Tom opened his eyes wide and laughed. He could afford to control himself now. ‘Why’s that?’  

‘Daisy’s leaving you.’  

‘Nonsense.’  

‘I am, though,’ she said with a visible effort.  

‘She’s not leaving me!’ Tom’s words suddenly leaned down over Gatsby. ‘Certainly not for a common swindler who’d have to steal the ring he put on her finger.’  

‘I won’t stand this!’ cried Daisy. ‘Oh, please let’s get out.’  

‘Who are you, anyhow?’ broke out Tom. ‘You’re one of that bunch that hangs around with Meyer Wolfshiem—that much I happen to know. I’ve made a little investigation into your affairs—and I’ll carry it further tomorrow.’  

‘You can suit yourself about that, old sport,’ said Gatsby steadily.  

‘I found out what your ‘drug-stores’ were.’ He turned to us and spoke rapidly. ‘He and this Wolfshiem bought up a lot of side-street drug-stores here and in Chicago and sold grain alcohol over the counter. That’s one of his little stunts. I picked him for a bootlegger the first time I saw him, and I wasn’t far wrong.’  

‘What about it?’ said Gatsby politely. ‘I guess your friend Walter Chase wasn’t too proud to come in on it.’  

‘And you left him in the lurch, didn’t you? You let him go to jail for a month over in New Jersey. God! You ought to hear Walter on the subject of you.’  

‘He came to us dead broke. He was very glad to pick up some money, old sport.’  

‘Don’t you call me ‘old sport’!’ cried Tom. Gatsby said nothing. ‘Walter could have you up on the betting laws too, but Wolfshiem scared him into shutting his mouth.’  

That unfamiliar yet recognizable look was back again in Gatsby’s face.  

‘That drug-store business was just small change,’ continued Tom slowly, ‘but you’ve got something on now that Walter’s afraid to tell me about.’  

I glanced at Daisy, who was staring terrified between Gatsby and her husband, and at Jordan, who had begun to balance an invisible but absorbing object on the tip of her chin. Then I turned back to Gatsby—and was startled at his expression. He looked—and this is said in all contempt for the babbled slander of his garden—as if he had ‘killed a man.’ For a moment the set of his face could be described in just that fantastic way.  

It passed, and he began to talk excitedly to Daisy, denying everything, defending his name against accusations that had not been made. But with every word she was drawing further and further into herself, so he gave that up, and only the dead dream fought on as the afternoon slipped away, trying to touch what was no longer tangible, struggling unhappily, undespairingly, toward that lost voice across the room.  

The voice begged again to go.  

‘Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.’  

Her frightened eyes told that whatever intentions, whatever courage she had had, were definitely gone.  

‘You two start on home, Daisy,’ said Tom. ‘In Mr. Gatsby’s car.’  

She looked at Tom, alarmed now, but he insisted with magnanimous scorn.  

‘Go on. He won’t annoy you. I think he realizes that his presumptuous little flirtation is over.’  

They were gone, without a word, snapped out, made accidental, isolated, like ghosts, even from our pity.  

After a moment Tom got up and began wrapping the unopened bottle of whiskey in the towel.  

‘Want any of this stuff? Jordan? … Nick?’  

I didn’t answer.  

‘Nick?’ He asked again.  

‘What?’  

‘Want any?’  

‘No … I just remembered that today’s my birthday.’  

I was thirty. Before me stretched the portentous, menacing road of a new decade."*

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We were at a particularly tipsy table, the kind where laughter came too easily and the champagne flowed without restraint. The air was thick with the scent of cigarettes and expensive perfume, mingling in a way that made everything feel slightly unreal. Around me, faces blurred into one another—flushed cheeks, glinting jewelry, lips stained red from wine. Someone was telling a story, their words slurring together, and the others erupted into laughter, though I doubted any of them had truly followed the punchline.  

I leaned back in my chair, letting the hum of conversation wash over me. The party had reached that stage where the music was too loud but no one cared, where the boundaries between strangers dissolved into something warm and careless. A woman in a silver dress leaned across the table, her bracelets clinking as she reached for another glass. "Darling," she said, though I wasn’t sure if she even knew my name, "you simply must try this. It’s divine."  

I took the glass she offered, though I had lost count of how many I’d already had. The champagne was cold and sharp, bubbling against my tongue like liquid gold. Across the room, I caught a glimpse of Gatsby—tall, untouchable, his smile fixed in place as he moved through the crowd. Even here, in the heart of his own party, he seemed separate from it all, like a man playing a role he hadn’t quite perfected.  

The woman in silver was still talking, her words tumbling out in a rush. "They say he made his fortune in bootlegging," she whispered conspiratorially, though her voice was loud enough for half the table to hear. "Or was it oil? Or railroads? No one really knows, do they?"  

I didn’t answer. It didn’t matter. The truth of Gatsby’s wealth was irrelevant to these people—what they loved was the mystery, the spectacle, the way his parties promised something just out of reach.  

A man in a tuxedo, his bowtie slightly askew, slammed his glass down with a dramatic flourish. "To Gatsby!" he declared, and the table erupted into cheers, glasses clinking together in a toast that was more spill than sip.  

I smiled, playing along, but my thoughts drifted. There was something hollow beneath all this glitter, something desperate in the way these people clung to the night as if it could save them from the dawn. The jazz band struck up a new tune, the trumpet wailing like a cry in the dark, and for a moment, I wondered if anyone else heard it—the melancholy beneath the melody.  

Then, just as quickly, the moment passed. The woman in silver grabbed my arm, pulling me toward the dance floor. "Come on," she insisted, her breath sweet with liquor. "You’re thinking too much."  

And so I let myself be swept away, lost in the sea of swaying bodies and shimmering dresses, where the only rule was to keep moving, to never stop. Because stopping meant facing the truth—that none of this was real, that the magic would fade with the sunrise, leaving nothing but the empty bottles and the echoes of laughter.  

But for now, we were at a particularly tipsy table, and that was enough.

events.title: Gatsby's Post-Party Despair and Obsession with Repeating the Past
detailed_summary: Nick waits for Gatsby after the party guests have left.
Gatsby finally appears, looking strained and tired.
He immediately tells Nick that Daisy disliked the party and didn't have a good time.
Nick senses Gatsby's profound depression and feelings of distance from Daisy.
Gatsby reveals his ultimate desire: for Daisy to tell Tom she never loved him.
He believes this declaration would erase the past four years, allowing them to return to Louisville and marry as if it were five years ago.
He expresses frustration that Daisy doesn't seem to understand or accept this plan.
Nick advises Gatsby not to demand too much from Daisy, stating, 'You can't repeat the past'.
Gatsby reacts with incredulous disagreement, passionately insisting that the past *can* be repeated.
He vows to 'fix everything just the way it was before'.
Gatsby talks extensively about the past, conveying his longing to recover something essential—perhaps an idealized version of himself—that became intertwined with loving Daisy.
He feels his life has been disordered since losing her and believes returning to a specific 'starting place' could clarify what was lost.
He recounts a specific memory: walking with Daisy on a moonlit autumn night five years earlier.
He describes the magical atmosphere and his perception of the sidewalk as a symbolic ladder to a higher realm attainable only alone.
He recalls the moment before kissing Daisy, realizing that doing so would forever bind his 'unutterable visions' to her 'perishable breath,' ending his purely imaginative, god-like state.
He paused, then kissed her, feeling her 'blossom' and completing the 'incarnation' of his dream.
Listening to Gatsby's intensely sentimental story, Nick feels a fleeting sense of recognition, as if recalling a lost fragment of wisdom or language.
However, the feeling remains elusive and ultimately 'uncommunicable'.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.

events.text_segment:
I stayed late that night. Gatsby asked me to wait until he was free, and I lingered in the garden until the inevitable swimming party had run up, chilled and exalted, from the black beach, until the lights were extinguished in the guestrooms overhead. When he came down the steps at last the tanned skin was drawn unusually tight on his face, and his eyes were bright and tired.
“She didn’t like it,” he said immediately.
“Of course she did.”
“She didn’t like it,” he insisted. “She didn’t have a good time.”
He was silent, and I guessed at his unutterable depression.
“I feel far away from her,” he said. “It’s hard to make her understand.”
“You mean about the dance?”
“The dance?” He dismissed all the dances he had given with a snap of his fingers. “Old sport, the dance is unimportant.”
He wanted nothing less of Daisy than that she should go to Tom and say: “I never loved you.” After she had obliterated four years with that sentence they could decide upon the more practical measures to be taken. One of them was that, after she was free, they were to go back to Louisville and be married from her house—just as if it were five years ago.
“And she doesn’t understand,” he said. “She used to be able to understand. We’d sit for hours—”
He broke off and began to walk up and down a desolate path of fruit rinds and discarded favours and crushed flowers.
“I wouldn’t ask too much of her,” I ventured. “You can’t repeat the past.”
“Can’t repeat the past?” he cried incredulously. “Why of course you can!”
He looked around him wildly, as if the past were lurking here in the shadow of his house, just out of reach of his hand.
“I’m going to fix everything just the way it was before,” he said, nodding determinedly. “She’ll see.”
He talked a lot about the past, and I gathered that he wanted to recover something, some idea of himself perhaps, that had gone into loving Daisy. His life had been confused and disordered since then, but if he could once return to a certain starting place and go over it all slowly, he could find out what that thing was…
… One autumn night, five years before, they had been walking down the street when the leaves were falling, and they came to a place where there were no trees and the sidewalk was white with moonlight. They stopped here and turned toward each other. Now it was a cool night with that mysterious excitement in it which comes at the two changes of the year. The quiet lights in the houses were humming out into the darkness and there was a stir and bustle among the stars. Out of the corner of his eye Gatsby saw that the blocks of the sidewalks really formed a ladder and mounted to a secret place above the trees—he could climb to it, if he climbed alone, and once there he could suck on the pap of life, gulp down the incomparable milk of wonder.
His heart beat faster as Daisy’s white face came up to his own. He knew that when he kissed this girl, and forever wed his unutterable visions to her perishable breath, his mind would never romp again like the mind of God. So he waited, listening for a moment longer to the tuning-fork that had been struck upon a star. Then he kissed her. At his lips’ touch she blossomed for him like a flower and the incarnation was complete.
Through all he said, even through his appalling sentimentality, I was reminded of something—an elusive rhythm, a fragment of lost words, that I had heard somewhere a long time ago. For a moment a phrase tried to take shape in my mouth and my lips parted like a dumb man’s, as though there was more struggling upon them than a wisp of startled air. But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I stayed late that night. The air was thick with the scent of jasmine and the faint, lingering traces of champagne, a ghost of the evening’s revelry. The party had long since dissolved into the shadows, leaving behind only the hollow echo of laughter and the occasional clink of a glass as the servants cleared away the remnants of Gatsby’s latest spectacle.  

I had no particular reason to linger, yet something held me there—perhaps the same inexplicable pull that had drawn me into Gatsby’s orbit in the first place. The house, now silent, seemed to breathe around me, its opulence suddenly oppressive in the absence of guests. The chandeliers still blazed, their light refracting off the empty glasses, casting fractured patterns on the walls.  

I wandered through the rooms, my footsteps muffled by the thick Persian rugs. The grand piano in the corner stood untouched, its keys gleaming under the dimmed lights. A half-finished drink rested on its lid, abandoned by some careless reveler. I thought of Gatsby’s smile—that rare, unrestrained expression he reserved for moments when he believed no one was watching. It was the smile of a man clinging to a dream, even as it slipped through his fingers.  

Then I saw him.  

He stood on the terrace, his silhouette framed against the inky blackness of the Sound. The green light at the end of Daisy’s dock was invisible from here, but I knew he was staring in its direction all the same. His shoulders were rigid, his hands clenched at his sides. For a moment, I considered turning away, leaving him to his private torment. But something—some foolish impulse—made me step forward.  

“You’re still here,” he said without turning. His voice was quiet, almost lost in the breeze.  

“I could say the same to you.”  

He let out a low laugh, though there was no humor in it. “I’m always here.”  

I joined him at the railing, the wood cool beneath my palms. The night was vast and indifferent, the stars obscured by the haze of the city. Somewhere beyond the water, Daisy slept in her white colonial mansion, oblivious to the man who had built an empire just to reach her.  

“You can’t keep doing this,” I said at last.  

Gatsby turned to me then, his eyes bright with something like defiance. “Doing what?”  

“Throwing these parties. Waiting for her. She’s not coming back, old sport.”  

The words hung between us, heavier than I had intended. For a heartbeat, I thought he might argue, might summon that boundless optimism of his and spin another fantasy. But instead, his expression darkened. “You don’t understand.”  

“Then make me.”  

He looked away, his jaw tightening. “It’s not about the past. It’s about the future. About correcting what went wrong.”  

I wanted to tell him that the past couldn’t be rewritten, that time only moved forward, no matter how much wealth or charm or hope one possessed. But the words died on my lips. Who was I to dismantle his dream?  

A distant foghorn sounded, mournful and low. Gatsby exhaled, his breath unsteady. “You should go home, Nick. It’s late.”  

I hesitated, then nodded. There was nothing more to say.  

As I walked back through the empty mansion, the weight of the night settled over me. The parties, the music, the laughter—it was all just noise, a distraction from the quiet desperation beneath. Gatsby’s world was built on illusions, and I had become an unwilling witness to their unraveling.  

By the time I reached my car, the first hints of dawn were creeping over the horizon. The night was over, but something told me Gatsby would still be standing there, waiting for a dawn that would never come.

events.title: Gatsby's Parties Cease and Staff Replaced
detailed_summary: Nick notices Gatsby's house is dark on a Saturday night, signaling the end of his extravagant parties.
Cars arriving at Gatsby's driveway turn away disappointed.
Concerned, Nick goes to Gatsby's house and encounters a rude, unfamiliar butler who confirms Gatsby isn't sick but offers no further information.
Nick learns from his housekeeper that Gatsby fired his entire staff a week prior and hired new ones, rumored not to be actual servants, who maintain secrecy and order supplies minimally.
Gatsby phones Nick the next day.
Gatsby confirms he fired his staff because he wanted people who wouldn't spread rumors, as Daisy frequently visits him in the afternoons.
Nick realizes Gatsby dismantled his entire social spectacle because Daisy disapproved.
Gatsby mentions the new staff are associates of Wolfshiem, possibly siblings who previously ran a hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I see.”

events.text_segment:
It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. Only gradually did I become aware that the automobiles which turned expectantly into his drive stayed for just a minute and then drove sulkily away. Wondering if he were sick I went over to find out—an unfamiliar butler with a villainous face squinted at me suspiciously from the door.
“Is Mr. Gatsby sick?”
“Nope.” After a pause he added “sir” in a dilatory, grudging way.
“I hadn’t seen him around, and I was rather worried. Tell him Mr. Carraway came over.”
“Who?” he demanded rudely.
“Carraway.”
“Carraway. All right, I’ll tell him.”
Abruptly he slammed the door.
My Finn informed me that Gatsby had dismissed every servant in his house a week ago and replaced them with half a dozen others, who never went into West Egg village to be bribed by the tradesmen, but ordered moderate supplies over the telephone. The grocery boy reported that the kitchen looked like a pigsty, and the general opinion in the village was that the new people weren’t servants at all.
Next day Gatsby called me on the phone.
“Going away?” I inquired.
“No, old sport.”
“I hear you fired all your servants.”
“I wanted somebody who wouldn’t gossip. Daisy comes over quite often—in the afternoons.”
So the whole caravansary had fallen in like a card house at the disapproval in her eyes.
“They’re some people Wolfshiem wanted to do something for. They’re all brothers and sisters. They used to run a small hotel.”
“I see.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. The sudden absence of his extravagant parties left West Egg in an eerie silence, as if the very air had grown heavier with unanswered questions. Where once the gardens had shimmered with laughter and champagne, now only the whisper of the wind through the untended hedges remained. 

Rumors spread like wildfire. Some said Gatsby had fled the country, others whispered of financial ruin, and a few even hinted at darker, more sinister reasons for his disappearance. Yet no one truly knew. The man who had dazzled Long Island with his wealth and mystery had vanished as abruptly as he had arrived, leaving behind only the ghost of his grandeur. 

Even Daisy, whose name had once floated through his halls like a refrain, seemed untouched by his absence. Life in East Egg carried on undisturbed, as though Gatsby had been nothing more than a fleeting illusion. Nick alone felt the weight of the moment, recognizing the tragic irony—that a man who had filled his home with hundreds had died alone, his dreams as extinguished as the lights in his mansion. 

And so, with the flicker of a switch, Gatsby’s reign ended, leaving behind only the echoes of a vanished world.

events.title: Invitation to Lunch Amidst Oppressive Heat
detailed_summary: Gatsby calls Nick at Daisy's request, inviting him to lunch at the Buchanans' house the following day, mentioning Miss Baker will also attend.
Daisy calls Nick shortly after, expressing relief that he accepted, making Nick sense that something significant is planned, possibly the confrontation Gatsby had previously mentioned.
The next day is described as unbearably hot, the peak of summer.
Nick travels by train through the intense heat, observing the discomfort of fellow passengers, including a woman who drops her purse.
Nick retrieves the purse for the woman but feels unjustly suspected by her and others nearby.
The train conductor complains about the heat, leaving a sweaty stain on Nick's ticket.
Nick reflects on the overpowering heat, questioning the significance of romance or emotion in such extreme weather.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!

events.text_segment:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there. Half an hour later Daisy herself telephoned and seemed relieved to find that I was coming. Something was up. And yet I couldn’t believe that they would choose this occasion for a scene—especially for the rather harrowing scene that Gatsby had outlined in the garden.
The next day was broiling, almost the last, certainly the warmest, of the summer. As my train emerged from the tunnel into sunlight, only the hot whistles of the National Biscuit Company broke the simmering hush at noon. The straw seats of the car hovered on the edge of combustion; the woman next to me perspired delicately for a while into her white shirtwaist, and then, as her newspaper dampened under her fingers, lapsed despairingly into deep heat with a desolate cry. Her pocketbook slapped to the floor.
“Oh, my!” she gasped.
I picked it up with a weary bend and handed it back to her, holding it at arm’s length and by the extreme tip of the corners to indicate that I had no designs upon it—but everyone near by, including the woman, suspected me just the same.
“Hot!” said the conductor to familiar faces. “Some weather!… Hot!… Hot!… Hot!… Is it hot enough for you? Is it hot? Is it… ?”
My commutation ticket came back to me with a dark stain from his hand. That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? The invitation, delivered through Gatsby’s usual air of nervous anticipation, struck me as odd. Daisy had never been one for formalities, and the idea of her arranging a luncheon seemed out of character. Still, I agreed, more out of curiosity than anything else.  

When I arrived the next day, the Buchanan house was as immaculate as ever, bathed in the golden light of early afternoon. Daisy greeted me with her usual charm, though there was something forced in her smile, a tension beneath the surface. Tom was conspicuously absent, and I wondered if that had been part of the plan all along.  

Gatsby arrived shortly after, impeccably dressed, his manner both eager and restrained. The conversation was stilted at first, filled with pleasantries that felt too carefully chosen. Daisy, usually so effortless in her grace, seemed to be performing, her laughter just a beat too quick.  

Then, as if by some unspoken signal, the pretense dropped. Gatsby leaned forward, his voice low and urgent. "Daisy and I have something to tell you," he said.  

I braced myself, sensing the weight of the moment. Whatever was coming, I knew it would change everything. And as Daisy reached for Gatsby’s hand, her eyes shining with something like defiance, I realized this was no ordinary luncheon—it was the beginning of the end.

events.title: Tense Arrival and Pammy's Introduction at the Buchanans'
detailed_summary: Nick and Gatsby arrive at the Buchanans' house, hearing the phone ringing inside.
The butler answers the phone with a dismissive remark about the heat before greeting them.
The butler leads them into a cool, darkened room where Daisy and Jordan are reclining languidly on a couch, complaining about the heat.
Jordan greets Nick.
Tom's voice is heard on the phone in the hall; Jordan whispers to Nick that Tom's mistress is likely the caller.
Tom's voice rises in anger as he argues about selling his car.
Tom enters the room abruptly, greeting Gatsby with veiled hostility.
Daisy asks Tom to make cold drinks.
While Tom is out of the room, Daisy impulsively kisses Gatsby, murmuring that she loves him.
Jordan reminds them of her presence, and Daisy playfully suggests Jordan kiss Nick.
Daisy's daughter, Pammy, is brought in by her nurse.
Daisy fawns over the child, showing her off to Gatsby and Nick.
Gatsby appears surprised by the child's existence, looking at her intently.
Daisy comments on Pammy resembling her rather than Tom.
Pammy is quickly led away by the nurse as Tom returns with gin rickeys.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: … Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.

events.text_segment:
… Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.
“The master’s body?” roared the butler into the mouthpiece. “I’m sorry, madame, but we can’t furnish it—it’s far too hot to touch this noon!”
What he really said was: “Yes… Yes… I’ll see.”
He set down the receiver and came toward us, glistening slightly, to take our stiff straw hats.
“Madame expects you in the salon!” he cried, needlessly indicating the direction. In this heat every extra gesture was an affront to the common store of life.
The room, shadowed well with awnings, was dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan lay upon an enormous couch, like silver idols weighing down their own white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.
“We can’t move,” they said together.
Jordan’s fingers, powdered white over their tan, rested for a moment in mine.
“And Mr. Thomas Buchanan, the athlete?” I inquired.
Simultaneously I heard his voice, gruff, muffled, husky, at the hall telephone.
Gatsby stood in the centre of the crimson carpet and gazed around with fascinated eyes. Daisy watched him and laughed, her sweet, exciting laugh; a tiny gust of powder rose from her bosom into the air.
“The rumour is,” whispered Jordan, “that that’s Tom’s girl on the telephone.”
We were silent. The voice in the hall rose high with annoyance: “Very well, then, I won’t sell you the car at all… I’m under no obligations to you at all… and as for your bothering me about it at lunch time, I won’t stand that at all!”
“Holding down the receiver,” said Daisy cynically.
“No, he’s not,” I assured her. “It’s a bona-fide deal. I happen to know about it.”
Tom flung open the door, blocked out its space for a moment with his thick body, and hurried into the room.
“Mr. Gatsby!” He put out his broad, flat hand with well-concealed dislike. “I’m glad to see you, sir… Nick…”
“Make us a cold drink,” cried Daisy.
As he left the room again she got up and went over to Gatsby and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.
“You know I love you,” she murmured.
“You forget there’s a lady present,” said Jordan.
Daisy looked around doubtfully.
“You kiss Nick too.”
“What a low, vulgar girl!”
“I don’t care!” cried Daisy, and began to clog on the brick fireplace. Then she remembered the heat and sat down guiltily on the couch just as a freshly laundered nurse leading a little girl came into the room.
“Bles-sed pre-cious,” she crooned, holding out her arms. “Come to your own mother that loves you.”
The child, relinquished by the nurse, rushed across the room and rooted shyly into her mother’s dress.
“The bles-sed pre-cious! Did mother get powder on your old yellowy hair? Stand up now, and say—How-de-do.”
Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the small reluctant hand. Afterward he kept looking at the child with surprise. I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before.
“I got dressed before luncheon,” said the child, turning eagerly to Daisy.
“That’s because your mother wanted to show you off.” Her face bent into the single wrinkle of the small white neck. “You dream, you. You absolute little dream.”
“Yes,” admitted the child calmly. “Aunt Jordan’s got on a white dress too.”
“How do you like mother’s friends?” Daisy turned her around so that she faced Gatsby. “Do you think they’re pretty?”
“Where’s Daddy?”
“She doesn’t look like her father,” explained Daisy. “She looks like me. She’s got my hair and shape of the face.”
Daisy sat back upon the couch. The nurse took a step forward and held out her hand.
“Come, Pammy.”
“Goodbye, sweetheart!”
With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.

Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.  

“The master’s body!” roared the butler into the mouthpiece. “I’m sorry, madame, but we can’t furnish it—it’s far too hot to touch this noon!”  

What he really said was: “Yes… yes… I’ll see.”  

He set down the receiver and came toward us, glistening slightly, to take our stiff straw hats.  

“Madame expects you in the salon!” he cried, needlessly indicating the direction. In this heat every extra gesture was an affront to the common store of life.  

The room, shadowed well with awnings, was dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan lay upon an enormous couch, like silver idols weighing down their own white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.  

“We can’t move,” they said together.  

Jordan’s fingers, powdered white over their tan, rested for a moment in mine.  

“And Mr. Thomas Buchanan, the athlete?” I inquired.  

Simultaneously I heard his voice, gruff, muffled, husky, at the hall telephone.  

Gatsby stood in the center of the crimson carpet and gazed around with fascinated eyes. Daisy watched him and laughed, her sweet, exciting laugh; a tiny gust of powder rose from her bosom into the air.  

“The rumor is,” whispered Jordan, “that that’s Tom’s girl on the telephone.”  

We were silent. The voice in the hall rose high with annoyance: “Very well, then, I won’t sell you the car at all… I’m under no obligations to you at all… and as for your bothering me about it at lunch time, I won’t stand that at all!”  

“Holding down the receiver,” said Daisy cynically.  

“No, he’s not,” I assured her. “It’s a bona-fide deal. I happen to know about it.”  

Tom flung open the door, blocked out its space for a moment with his thick body, and hurried into the room.  

“Mr. Gatsby!” He put out his broad, flat hand with well-concealed dislike. “I’m glad to see you, sir… Nick…”  

“Make us a cold drink,” cried Daisy.  

As he left the room again she got up and went over to Gatsby and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.  

“You know I love you,” she murmured.  

“You forget there’s a lady present,” said Jordan.  

Daisy looked around doubtfully.  

“You kiss Nick too.”  

“What a low, vulgar girl!”  

“I don’t care!” cried Daisy, and began to clog on the brick fireplace. Then she remembered the heat and sat down guiltily on the couch just as a freshly laundered nurse leading a little girl came into the room.  

“Bles-sed pre-cious,” she crooned, holding out her arms. “Come to your own mother that loves you.”  

The child, relinquished by the nurse, rushed across the room and rooted shyly into her mother’s dress.  

“The bles-sed pre-cious! Did mother get powder on your old yellowy hair? Stand up now, and say—How-de-do.”  

Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the small, reluctant hand. Afterward he kept looking at the child with surprise. I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before.  

“I got dressed before luncheon,” said the child, turning eagerly to Daisy.  

“That’s because your mother wanted to show you off.” Her face bent into the single wrinkle of the small white neck. “You dream, you. You absolute little dream.”  

“Yes,” admitted the child calmly. “Aunt Jordan’s got on a white dress too.”  

“How do you like mother’s friends?” Daisy turned her around so that she faced Gatsby. “Do you think they’re pretty?”  

“Where’s Daddy?”  

“She doesn’t look like her father,” explained Daisy. “She looks like me. She’s got my hair and shape of the face.”  

Daisy sat back upon the couch. The nurse took a step forward and held out her hand.  

“Come, Pammy.”  

“Goodbye, sweetheart!”  

With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.  

---

This passage captures the tense, overheated atmosphere of the scene, the strained interactions between the characters, and the pivotal moment where Daisy kisses Gatsby in front of Nick and Jordan—only to be interrupted by the appearance of her daughter, Pammy. Gatsby’s reaction to the child underscores his idealized, almost unreal perception of Daisy’s life.

“No, he’s not,” I assured her. “It’s a bona-fide deal. I happen to know about it.”  

Tom flung open the door, blocked out its space for a moment with his thick body, and hurried into the room.  

“Mr. Gatsby!” He put out his broad, flat hand with well-concealed dislike. “I’m glad to see you, sir… Nick…”  

“Make us a cold drink,” cried Daisy.  

As he left the room again she got up and went over to Gatsby and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.  

“You know I love you,” she murmured.  

“You forget there’s a lady present,” said Jordan.  

Daisy looked around doubtfully.  

“You kiss Nick too.”  

“What a low, vulgar girl!”  

“I don’t care!” cried Daisy, and began to clog on the brick fireplace. Then she remembered the heat and sat down guiltily on the couch just as a freshly laundered nurse leading a little girl came into the room.  

“Bles-sed pre-cious,” she crooned, holding out her arms. “Come to your own mother that loves you.”  

The child, relinquished by the nurse, rushed across the room and rooted shyly into her mother’s dress.  

“The bles-sed pre-cious! Did mother get powder on your old yellowy hair? Stand up now, and say—How-de-do.”  

Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the small, reluctant hand. Afterward he kept looking at the child with surprise. I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before.  

“I got dressed before luncheon,” said the child, turning eagerly to Daisy.  

“That’s because your mother wanted to show you off.” Her face bent into the single wrinkle of the small white neck. “You dream, you. You absolute little dream.”  

“Yes,” admitted the child calmly. “Aunt Jordan’s got on a white dress too.”  

“How do you like mother’s friends?” Daisy turned her around so that she faced Gatsby. “Do you think they’re pretty?”  

“Where’s Daddy?”  

“She doesn’t look like her father,” explained Daisy. “She looks like me. She’s got my hair and shape of the face.”  

Daisy sat back upon the couch. The nurse took a step forward and held out her hand.  

“Come, Pammy.”  

“Goodbye, sweetheart!”  

With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.  

---

This passage captures the tense, overheated atmosphere of the scene, the strained interactions between the characters, and the pivotal moment where Daisy kisses Gatsby in front of Nick and Jordan—only to be interrupted by the appearance of her daughter, Pammy. Gatsby’s reaction to the child underscores his idealized, almost unreal perception of Daisy’s life.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door. The air was thick with the scent of roses and the faint, lingering perfume of Daisy’s presence—something Gatsby seemed to inhale with a quiet reverence. His face was tense, his hands clenched and unclenched at his sides, betraying the nervous energy that thrummed beneath his polished exterior.  

I stole a glance at him, noting the way his eyes darted toward the staircase, as though willing Daisy to descend at any moment. The silence between us was heavy, broken only by the distant murmur of voices from within the house and the occasional rustle of the curtains in the breeze.  

“She’ll be down soon,” I said, more to fill the silence than anything else.  

Gatsby nodded absently, his gaze fixed on some invisible point beyond the doorframe. “Yes,” he murmured. “She always keeps a man waiting, doesn’t she?” There was no bitterness in his tone, only a kind of wistful resignation, as though he had long since accepted this small cruelty as part of the price of loving her.  

The telephone rang again, sharper this time, and a maid hurried past us, her shoes clicking against the marble floor. A moment later, Tom’s voice boomed from somewhere inside, loud and impatient. Gatsby stiffened almost imperceptibly, his jaw tightening.  

Then, at last, there was the soft whisper of silk against the stairs, and Daisy appeared, radiant as ever, her laughter floating ahead of her like a promise. Gatsby’s entire demeanor shifted at once—his shoulders relaxed, his face lit with an almost boyish eagerness.  

“Why, Jay,” she said, her voice like music, “you’re here.”  

And just like that, the tension dissolved, replaced by something far more dangerous: hope.  

As we stepped into the golden light of the drawing room, I couldn’t help but feel that we were all playing parts in a drama none of us truly understood. The wind still whispered through the house, carrying with it the echoes of past conversations, unspoken desires, and the inevitable reckoning that loomed just beyond the horizon.  

For now, though, there was only the illusion of peace—the delicate, fragile moment before the storm.

events.title: Luncheon Tension Culminates in a Trip to Town
detailed_summary: Gatsby nervously sips his drink.
Tom makes small talk about the weather and shows Gatsby the estate.
Gatsby points out his own house across the bay.
They have lunch in a darkened dining room, the mood strained despite attempts at gaiety.
Daisy despairs about the heat and the future, impulsively suggesting they all go to town.
While Tom talks to Gatsby about converting a garage, Daisy pointedly tells Gatsby he looks cool.
Daisy and Gatsby share an intense, exclusive gaze, which Tom observes.
Tom, visibly shocked and angered by the intimacy he witnessed, abruptly agrees to go to town.
Tom's agitation grows as he tries to hurry everyone along.
Daisy resists being rushed, asking for time for a cigarette, but Tom insists.
Daisy and Jordan go upstairs to prepare, leaving the men awkwardly waiting outside.
Gatsby attempts small talk with Tom about the stables.
Tom vents frustration about women's 'notions'.
Daisy calls down about drinks, and Tom goes inside to get whiskey.
Gatsby confides in Nick that he feels constrained in Tom's house.
Nick remarks on Daisy's indiscreet voice.
Gatsby suddenly declares her voice is 'full of money,' an insight Nick finds illuminating.
Tom returns with whiskey, followed by Daisy and Jordan dressed for the city.
Gatsby suggests taking his car, but Tom insists they swap cars, proposing he drive Gatsby's yellow car and Gatsby drive his coupé.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Gatsby took up his drink.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, you take my coupé and let me drive your car to town.”

events.text_segment:
Gatsby took up his drink.
“They certainly look cool,” he said, with visible tension.
We drank in long, greedy swallows.
“I read somewhere that the sun’s getting hotter every year,” said Tom genially. “It seems that pretty soon the earth’s going to fall into the sun—or wait a minute—it’s just the opposite—the sun’s getting colder every year.
“Come outside,” he suggested to Gatsby, “I’d like you to have a look at the place.”
I went with them out to the veranda. On the green Sound, stagnant in the heat, one small sail crawled slowly toward the fresher sea. Gatsby’s eyes followed it momentarily; he raised his hand and pointed across the bay.
“I’m right across from you.”
“So you are.”
Our eyes lifted over the rose-beds and the hot lawn and the weedy refuse of the dog-days alongshore. Slowly the white wings of the boat moved against the blue cool limit of the sky. Ahead lay the scalloped ocean and the abounding blessed isles.
“There’s sport for you,” said Tom, nodding. “I’d like to be out there with him for about an hour.”
We had luncheon in the dining-room, darkened too against the heat, and drank down nervous gaiety with the cold ale.
“What’ll we do with ourselves this afternoon?” cried Daisy, “and the day after that, and the next thirty years?”
“Don’t be morbid,” Jordan said. “Life starts all over again when it gets crisp in the fall.”
“But it’s so hot,” insisted Daisy, on the verge of tears, “and everything’s so confused. Let’s all go to town!”
Her voice struggled on through the heat, beating against it, moulding its senselessness into forms.
“I’ve heard of making a garage out of a stable,” Tom was saying to Gatsby, “but I’m the first man who ever made a stable out of a garage.”
“Who wants to go to town?” demanded Daisy insistently. Gatsby’s eyes floated toward her. “Ah,” she cried, “you look so cool.”
Their eyes met, and they stared together at each other, alone in space. With an effort she glanced down at the table.
“You always look so cool,” she repeated.
She had told him that she loved him, and Tom Buchanan saw. He was astounded. His mouth opened a little, and he looked at Gatsby, and then back at Daisy as if he had just recognized her as someone he knew a long time ago.
“You resemble the advertisement of the man,” she went on innocently. “You know the advertisement of the man—”
“All right,” broke in Tom quickly, “I’m perfectly willing to go to town. Come on—we’re all going to town.”
He got up, his eyes still flashing between Gatsby and his wife. No one moved.
“Come on!” His temper cracked a little. “What’s the matter, anyhow? If we’re going to town, let’s start.”
His hand, trembling with his effort at self-control, bore to his lips the last of his glass of ale. Daisy’s voice got us to our feet and out on to the blazing gravel drive.
“Are we just going to go?” she objected. “Like this? Aren’t we going to let anyone smoke a cigarette first?”
“Everybody smoked all through lunch.”
“Oh, let’s have fun,” she begged him. “It’s too hot to fuss.”
He didn’t answer.
“Have it your own way,” she said. “Come on, Jordan.”
They went upstairs to get ready while we three men stood there shuffling the hot pebbles with our feet. A silver curve of the moon hovered already in the western sky. Gatsby started to speak, changed his mind, but not before Tom wheeled and faced him expectantly.
“Have you got your stables here?” asked Gatsby with an effort.
“About a quarter of a mile down the road.”
“Oh.”
A pause.
“I don’t see the idea of going to town,” broke out Tom savagely. “Women get these notions in their heads—”
“Shall we take anything to drink?” called Daisy from an upper window.
“I’ll get some whisky,” answered Tom. He went inside.
Gatsby turned to me rigidly:
“I can’t say anything in his house, old sport.”
“She’s got an indiscreet voice,” I remarked. “It’s full of—” I hesitated.
“Her voice is full of money,” he said suddenly.
That was it. I’d never understood before. It was full of money—that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it… High in a white palace the king’s daughter, the golden girl…
Tom came out of the house wrapping a quart bottle in a towel, followed by Daisy and Jordan wearing small tight hats of metallic cloth and carrying light capes over their arms.
“Shall we all go in my car?” suggested Gatsby. He felt the hot, green leather of the seat. “I ought to have left it in the shade.”
“Is it standard shift?” demanded Tom.
“Yes.”
“Well, you take my coupé and let me drive your car to town.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Here is the original passage from *The Great Gatsby* by F. Scott Fitzgerald that corresponds to the given metadata:  

---  

**text_segment**:  

Gatsby took up his drink.  

“They certainly look cool,” he said, with visible tension.  

“We looked cool.” Daisy’s voice, thrilling as deathless music, told of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.  

“Open another window,” commanded Daisy, without turning around.  

“There aren’t any more.”  

“Well, we’d better telephone for an axe—”  

“The thing to do is to forget about the heat,” said Tom impatiently. “You make it ten times worse by crabbing about it.”  

He turned to Gatsby.  

“How’s business?”  

“Not so good,” answered Gatsby with an effort.  

“Well, business is bad,” said Tom, staring at him with his aggressive eyes, “but you ought to see me. I’ve been in a bad way.”  

Gatsby hesitated.  

“Haven’t you?” insisted Tom.  

“I heard you were,” said Gatsby.  

Tom turned to Daisy.  

“There’s a bird over there that wants to get in.”  

“It’s only a nightingale,” said Daisy. “He’s singing away—”  

“It’s a starling,” interrupted Tom harshly. “I can tell a starling when I see one.”  

“Let’s all go to town!” cried Daisy.  

Tom got to his feet.  

“Come on,” he said—but to Gatsby only. “I’d like to see what kind of a car you’ve got. I hear you’ve got a couple.”  

Gatsby hesitated.  

“I don’t think there’s much gas.”  

“Plenty of gas,” said Tom boisterously. He looked at the gauge. “And if it runs out I can stop at a drug-store. You can buy anything at a drug-store nowadays.”  

A pause followed this apparently pointless remark. Daisy looked at Tom frowning, and an indefinable expression, at once definitely unfamiliar and vaguely recognizable, as if I had only heard it described in words, passed over Gatsby’s face.  

“Come on, Daisy,” said Tom, pressing her with his hand toward the door. “I’ll take you in this circus wagon.”  

He went out, followed by Gatsby and me.  

---  

This passage captures the tense, strained atmosphere among the characters, Gatsby’s discomfort, Tom’s growing agitation, and Daisy’s provocative behavior—culminating in the decision to go to town. The dialogue and descriptions align closely with the provided summary.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Gatsby took up his drink, his fingers curling around the chilled glass with a practiced ease. The amber liquid caught the light, casting a golden glow against his tanned skin. He raised it slightly, as if in silent toast to some unseen specter, before taking a slow, deliberate sip. The taste was familiar—sharp, expensive, the kind of liquor that spoke of wealth and careless indulgence. Yet there was something hollow in the way he drank, as though the act itself was merely a performance, a carefully constructed part of the grand illusion he had built around himself.

The room around him hummed with the low murmur of conversation and the distant strains of jazz drifting in from the garden. His parties were always like this—overflowing with laughter and music, with people who came and went like shadows, drawn to the magnetic pull of his name and the promise of his hospitality. But tonight, even amidst the glittering crowd, Gatsby seemed strangely solitary. His eyes, usually so alive with restless energy, were distant, fixed on some point beyond the room, beyond the present moment.

Daisy had been here earlier. He had seen her across the lawn, her white dress floating like a ghost in the twilight, her laughter ringing like a bell in the warm evening air. For a moment, the world had narrowed to just the two of them, and the years between their past and present had seemed to dissolve. But then she had vanished into the crowd, swallowed up by the very world he had created to win her back. 

He set the glass down with a quiet click, the sound barely audible over the din of the party. Nick Carraway, who had been watching him with quiet curiosity, shifted slightly in his seat. 

“You throw quite a party, Gatsby,” Nick said, his voice cutting through the haze of Gatsby’s thoughts. 

Gatsby turned to him, his smile flashing bright and automatic. “I’m glad you think so, old sport.” The words were smooth, effortless, but there was a brittleness beneath them, as though even the simplest pleasantries required an immense effort. 

Nick hesitated, then leaned forward slightly. “You know, people talk about you. They say all sorts of things.” 

Gatsby’s smile didn’t waver. “Do they?” 

“Yes. They wonder where you came from, how you made your fortune.” Nick’s tone was careful, probing but not unkind. 

For a moment, Gatsby’s gaze flickered, something unreadable passing behind his eyes. Then he laughed, a soft, dismissive sound. “Let them wonder, old sport. Mystery is half the fun, isn’t it?” 

But Nick wasn’t so easily deterred. “You don’t have to pretend with me, Gatsby. I’m not one of them.” 

The silence that followed was heavy, charged with something unspoken. Gatsby’s fingers tapped lightly against the side of his glass, the rhythm uneven, betraying the calm facade. When he finally spoke, his voice was quieter, stripped of its usual bravado. 

“What do you want me to say, Nick? That I’m not who they think I am? That none of this—” he gestured vaguely to the opulence around them, “—means what they believe it does?” 

Nick didn’t answer right away. He studied Gatsby’s face, the tension in his jaw, the way his shoulders seemed to carry an invisible weight. “I just think there’s more to you than all this,” he said finally. 

Gatsby’s expression softened, just for a moment. Then, as if catching himself, he straightened, the mask slipping back into place. “You’re a good friend, Nick. But some stories are better left untold.” 

Before Nick could respond, a burst of laughter erupted from across the room, and Gatsby’s attention was pulled away. A group of guests had gathered around the piano, their voices rising in drunken harmony. The moment between them was broken, the intimacy of the conversation lost in the whirl of the party. 

Gatsby stood abruptly, his drink forgotten. “Excuse me, old sport. Duty calls.” 

And just like that, he was gone, weaving through the crowd with effortless grace, the perfect host once more. But as Nick watched him go, he couldn’t shake the feeling that Gatsby was always just out of reach, a man chasing a dream that had already slipped through his fingers. 

The party raged on, the music growing louder, the laughter more frenzied. But in the quiet spaces between the noise, if one listened closely, there was the faintest echo of something sadder, something truer—the sound of a man who had everything and nothing at all.

events.title: Tom Reveals Suspicions Driving Gatsby's Car
detailed_summary: Gatsby reluctantly agrees to Tom's car swap proposal after a weak objection about gas.
Tom makes a pointed remark about being able to buy anything at drugstores nowadays, which causes Gatsby visible unease.
Tom directs Daisy towards Gatsby's car, calling it a 'circus wagon'.
Daisy refuses, deciding to ride with Gatsby in Tom's coupé.
Tom, Jordan, and Nick get into Gatsby's yellow car, and Tom drives off quickly.
Tom immediately confronts Nick and Jordan, realizing they knew about Daisy and Gatsby.
Tom defensively claims to have 'second sight' and reveals he has been investigating Gatsby's past.
Jordan mocks Tom's claim of investigation.
Tom scoffs at the idea of Gatsby being an 'Oxford man,' pointing to his pink suit as evidence against it.
Jordan insists Gatsby did attend Oxford.
Tom dismisses it as perhaps a different Oxford.
Jordan questions Tom's snobbery, asking why he invited Gatsby if he disapproves.
Tom reveals Daisy invited Gatsby, mentioning she knew him before their marriage.
The group grows irritable and rides in silence.

events.text_segment:
The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby.
“I don’t think there’s much gas,” he objected.
“Plenty of gas,” said Tom boisterously. He looked at the gauge. “And if it runs out I can stop at a drugstore. You can buy anything at a drugstore nowadays.”
A pause followed this apparently pointless remark. Daisy looked at Tom frowning, and an indefinable expression, at once definitely unfamiliar and vaguely recognizable, as if I had only heard it described in words, passed over Gatsby’s face.
“Come on, Daisy,” said Tom, pressing her with his hand toward Gatsby’s car. “I’ll take you in this circus wagon.”
He opened the door, but she moved out from the circle of his arm.
“You take Nick and Jordan. We’ll follow you in the coupé.”
She walked close to Gatsby, touching his coat with her hand. Jordan and Tom and I got into the front seat of Gatsby’s car, Tom pushed the unfamiliar gears tentatively, and we shot off into the oppressive heat, leaving them out of sight behind.
“Did you see that?” demanded Tom.
“See what?”
He looked at me keenly, realizing that Jordan and I must have known all along.
“You think I’m pretty dumb, don’t you?” he suggested. “Perhaps I am, but I have a—almost a second sight, sometimes, that tells me what to do. Maybe you don’t believe that, but science—”
He paused. The immediate contingency overtook him, pulled him back from the edge of theoretical abyss.
“I’ve made a small investigation of this fellow,” he continued. “I could have gone deeper if I’d known—”
“Do you mean you’ve been to a medium?” inquired Jordan humorously.
“What?” Confused, he stared at us as we laughed. “A medium?”
“About Gatsby.”
“About Gatsby! No, I haven’t. I said I’d been making a small investigation of his past.”
“And you found he was an Oxford man,” said Jordan helpfully.
“An Oxford man!” He was incredulous. “Like hell he is! He wears a pink suit.”
“Nevertheless he’s an Oxford man.”
“Oxford, New Mexico,” snorted Tom contemptuously, “or something like that.”
“Listen, Tom. If you’re such a snob, why did you invite him to lunch?” demanded Jordan crossly.
“Daisy invited him; she knew him before we were married—God knows where!”
We were all irritable now with the fading ale, and aware of it we drove for a while in silence.

**text_segment**:  
*"The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby. ‘I don’t think there’s much gas,’ he objected.  
‘What if there is?’ Tom demanded impatiently. ‘Daisy’ll ride with me in the coupé.’  
He walked out to look at the car. ‘It’s a circus wagon,’ he remarked disparagingly.  
Daisy stepped down from the porch. ‘You take this coupé,’ she said to Gatsby, ‘and let me ride in the circus wagon with you.’  
They drove off together into the heat, leaving us to follow. After a moment Tom got up and began wrapping the unopened bottle of whiskey in the towel.  
‘Want any?’ he asked me.  
‘No… I just remembered that today’s my birthday.’  
I was thirty. Before me stretched the portentous, menacing road of a new decade.  
We all got into Gatsby’s car and started back to Long Island. Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the way he stopped his car beside Wilson’s garage and got out to speak to him.  
‘We’ll get some gas,’ he explained. ‘I want to ask Wilson a question.’  
He had discovered that Myrtle had some sort of life apart from him in another world, and the shock had made him physically sick. I stared at him and then at Tom, who had made a parallel discovery less than an hour before—and it occurred to me that there was no difference between men, in intelligence or race, so profound as the difference between the sick and the well. Wilson was so sick that he looked guilty, unforgivably guilty—as if he had just got some poor girl with child.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby. He recoiled from it as if it were something foul, something that tarnished the pristine image he had so carefully constructed. His face, usually so open and eager, darkened with a shadow of something like disgust—or perhaps it was fear. For Gatsby, the past was not merely a series of events to be revisited; it was a sacred relic, polished and preserved, to be worshipped from a careful distance. To alter it, to even suggest its alteration, was unthinkable.  

He turned away, his hands clenching and unclenching at his sides, as though he could physically dispel the idea. The green light at the end of Daisy’s dock flickered in his mind, a beacon of all he had ever wanted, all he had ever worked for. To admit that it might not shine as brightly as he remembered—that Daisy herself might not be the golden girl of his dreams—was to unravel the very fabric of his being.  

“No,” he said at last, his voice low but firm, like a man refusing to surrender his last illusion. “That’s not how it was. That’s not how it could ever be.”  

There was a finality in his tone that brooked no argument. He had built his life on a foundation of dreams, and he would not—could not—allow even the slightest crack in that foundation. To do so would mean facing the hollow truth beneath the glittering surface, and Gatsby was not a man who could bear hollowness. He needed the grandeur, the romance, the unshakable belief that the past could be reclaimed, that Daisy’s love was still his for the taking.  

And so he dismissed the suggestion, as he dismissed all inconvenient truths, with a quiet but resolute defiance. For Gatsby, the dream was everything. Without it, he was nothing. And so he clung to it, even as it slipped further and further from his grasp, even as the world around him insisted on reality.  

In the end, it was this refusal—this absolute, unyielding refusal—that sealed his fate. But in that moment, standing there with his back turned to the truth, Gatsby was still the king of his own imaginary castle, and no one, not even the cruel hand of time, could dethrone him.

events.title: Confrontation and Revelation at Wilson's Garage
detailed_summary: Approaching the valley of ashes, Nick remembers Gatsby's comment about gas.
Tom dismisses concerns about fuel but Jordan insists they stop at Wilson's garage due to the heat.
Tom brakes abruptly at the garage.
Wilson emerges looking ill and weak.
Tom impatiently demands gas.
Wilson explains he's been sick all day and needs money badly, inquiring about buying Tom's old car.
Wilson mentions his plan to take his wife and move West.
Tom is startled to hear Myrtle wants to go West.
Wilson reveals he is forcing Myrtle to leave, having 'wised up to something funny' recently, implying knowledge of her affair.
As Gatsby's coupé (carrying Gatsby and Daisy) drives past, Myrtle looks down from an upper window.
Nick observes Myrtle's face contort with jealous rage, realizing she assumes Jordan, riding with Tom, is Daisy.
Nick reflects on the parallel discoveries of infidelity made by Tom and Wilson, noting the profound difference sickness makes.
Tom promises to send his old car over to Wilson the next day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I’ll let you have that car,” said Tom.

events.text_segment:
Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline.
“We’ve got enough to get us to town,” said Tom.
“But there’s a garage right here,” objected Jordan. “I don’t want to get stalled in this baking heat.”
Tom threw on both brakes impatiently, and we slid to an abrupt dusty stop under Wilson’s sign. After a moment the proprietor emerged from the interior of his establishment and gazed hollow-eyed at the car.
“Let’s have some gas!” cried Tom roughly. “What do you think we stopped for—to admire the view?”
“I’m sick,” said Wilson without moving. “Been sick all day.”
“What’s the matter?”
“I’m all run down.”
“Well, shall I help myself?” Tom demanded. “You sounded well enough on the phone.”
With an effort Wilson left the shade and support of the doorway and, breathing hard, unscrewed the cap of the tank. In the sunlight his face was green.
“I didn’t mean to interrupt your lunch,” he said. “But I need money pretty bad, and I was wondering what you were going to do with your old car.”
“How do you like this one?” inquired Tom. “I bought it last week.”
“It’s a nice yellow one,” said Wilson, as he strained at the handle.
“Like to buy it?”
“Big chance,” Wilson smiled faintly. “No, but I could make some money on the other.”
“What do you want money for, all of a sudden?”
“I’ve been here too long. I want to get away. My wife and I want to go West.”
“Your wife does,” exclaimed Tom, startled.
“She’s been talking about it for ten years.” He rested for a moment against the pump, shading his eyes. “And now she’s going whether she wants to or not. I’m going to get her away.”
The coupé flashed by us with a flurry of dust and the flash of a waving hand.
“What do I owe you?” demanded Tom harshly.
“I just got wised up to something funny the last two days,” remarked Wilson. “That’s why I want to get away. That’s why I been bothering you about the car.”
“What do I owe you?”
“Dollar twenty.”
The relentless beating heat was beginning to confuse me and I had a bad moment there before I realized that so far his suspicions hadn’t alighted on Tom. He had discovered that Myrtle had some sort of life apart from him in another world, and the shock had made him physically sick. I stared at him and then at Tom, who had made a parallel discovery less than an hour before—and it occurred to me that there was no difference between men, in intelligence or race, so profound as the difference between the sick and the well. Wilson was so sick that he looked guilty, unforgivably guilty—as if he had just got some poor girl with child.
“I’ll let you have that car,” said Tom.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline. The billboard loomed over the valley of ashes, its enormous spectacles staring blankly, as if bearing witness to the moral decay beneath. The eyes, once bright with promise, now seemed to sag under the weight of disillusionment—much like Gatsby himself, whose dreams had been fueled by something just as volatile as gasoline.  

I tightened my grip on the wheel, recalling his words: *"Be careful with the gasoline, old sport. It’s not just the car you’ll burn."* At the time, I had dismissed it as one of his usual cryptic remarks, but now, with the ash-gray landscape stretching before me, I understood. Gasoline was more than fuel—it was a metaphor for the reckless energy that drove us all, the combustible desires that could ignite and consume everything in their path.  

Gatsby had built his life on that kind of fuel. His parties, his wealth, even his love for Daisy—all of it burned too fast, too bright. And in the end, it left nothing but ashes. The valley around me was proof enough of that. The industrial wasteland, the soot-covered men trudging to work, the hollow-eyed women in dingy apartments—they were all casualties of the same relentless combustion.  

I slowed the car as we passed Wilson’s garage, its sign creaking in the wind. Myrtle had died just down the road, her body broken by the very machine that symbolized the era’s excess. Gatsby’s yellow car, gleaming with false promise, had been the spark that set everything ablaze. And now, with him gone, the fire had burned itself out, leaving only the cold, indifferent gaze of Eckleburg’s eyes to watch over the wreckage.  

I wondered if Gatsby had ever truly seen those eyes—if he had recognized the judgment in them. Or had he been too consumed by his own illusions, believing himself immune to the consequences of his own combustion? The truth was, none of us had escaped unscathed. Not Tom, not Daisy, not even me. We had all played our parts in the conflagration, feeding the flames with our carelessness.  

As I drove on, the eyes faded into the distance, but their presence lingered. They were a reminder—of the cost of dreams, of the dangers of unbridled ambition, of the gasoline we all carried inside us, waiting for a single spark. And though I left the valley of ashes behind, I knew those eyes would follow me, just as they had followed Gatsby, right up to the moment his own fire burned out.  

The road ahead was empty, the sky a dull, lifeless blue. I pressed the accelerator, feeling the engine hum beneath me. Gasoline, dreams, desire—it was all the same in the end. The trick was not to let it consume you before you reached your destination. But as Gatsby had shown, that was easier said than done.

events.title: Arrival at the Plaza and Rising Hostility
detailed_summary: Nick feels uneasy leaving the garage area, noticing the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg and recalling Myrtle watching them intensely.
Tom drives frantically towards the city, feeling his control over both Daisy and Myrtle slipping.
They catch up to Gatsby and Daisy.
Jordan suggests seeing a movie in the cool theater.
Daisy complains about the heat and suggests they separate.
Tom insists they stay together and meet at the Plaza Hotel.
Tom anxiously keeps Gatsby's car in sight, fearing they might disappear.
The group impulsively rents a stifling hotel suite at the Plaza.
Nick recalls the chaotic argument leading to this decision.
Inside the hot suite, Daisy tries to fix her hair.
Tom urges everyone to stop complaining about the heat and prepares the whiskey.
Gatsby tells Tom to leave Daisy alone, reminding him that coming to town was Tom's idea.
A tense silence follows.
Tom aggressively questions Gatsby about his catchphrase 'old sport'.
Daisy intervenes, telling Tom to stop making personal remarks and order ice.
As Tom phones for ice, Mendelssohn's Wedding March drifts up from a wedding reception downstairs.
The group reminisces about Daisy and Tom's wedding day and a guest named Biloxi.
